titlePage.docImprint: One afternoon shortly before theNew York“ opening ” of this comedy a most estimable lady sat down to make me a cup of tea . “ Now , do tell me , what is your play about ? ” she inquired with commendable enthusiasm . For , being a true woman , she had early achieved the becoming habit of letting members of the superior sex talk about themselves .

docTitle.titlePart: “ ‘ Why Marry ? ’ ” said I , “ tells the truth about marriage . ”

epigraph.p: “ Oh , why , ” she expostulated , “ why write unpleasant plays ? ” “ But it is not ‘ unpleasant . ’ ” “ Then it is n't true ! ” she exclaimed . “ That is , I mean — I mean — did you say cream or lemon ? ” And in the pause which accompanied the pouring of the cream I detected the look of one realizing too late that it is always better to think before speaking . This little incident , it seemed to me , epitomizes charmingly the attitude of “ our nicest people ” toward our fundamental institution . The truth about marriage must be unpleasant . Therefore , tell us something we know is n't true . It will be so much nicer for our young people . It is to be feared , however , that young people who go to see “ Why Marry ? ” in the hope of being shocked do not get their money 's worth . I have heard of but two persons who have been scandalized by this play , and they were both old people . One was a woman in the country who had not seen it , but had read the title , and so wrote several indignant letters about it . The other was an elderly bachelor of the type which finds useful occupation in decorating club windows like geraniums . He took his niece to see it , and , deciding at the end of Act II that the play was going to be unpleasant in Act III , took her home at once . The next afternoon she appeared at the matinee with a whole bevy of her own generation and saw the rest of the play . I asked her later if it had shocked any of them . “ Oh , no , ” she replied , “ we are too young to be shocked . ” That little incident also struck me as socially significant . There never were two generations inhabiting the same globe simultaneously with such widely separated points of view .

front.performance: For several years after this play was first published no theatrical manager on Broadway would produce it . I do n't blame them , I want to thank them for it . I doubt if this sort of thing could have appealed to many theatre-goers then , especially as my young lovers are trying to be good , not bad . “ Self-expression ” and “ the right to happiness ” do not enter into their plans . The causes of their courageous and , of course , mistaken decision are unselfish and social motives , however futile and antisocial the results would have been had not their desperate determination been thwarted .... When this play was first published most people were not thinking along these lines . Such ideas were considered radical then . They will soon be old-fashioned — even on the stage . Kind and discriminating as the critics have been in regard to this comedy ( a discriminating critic being , of course , one who praises your play ) , few of them have seen the point which I thought I was making emphatically clear , namely , that we can n't cure social defects by individual treatment . Not only the lovers , but all the characters in this play are trying to do right according to their lights . There is no villain in this piece . At least the villain remains “ off stage . ” Perhaps that is why so few see him . You are the villain , you and I and the rest of society . We are responsible for the rules and regulations of the marriage game . Instead of having fun with human nature , I tried to go higher up and have fun with human institutions . I say “ tried , ” because apparently I did not succeed . The joke is on me . Still , I can get some amusement out of it : for a great many people seem to like this play who would be indignant if they knew what they were really applauding . They think they are merely enjoying “ satire on human nature . ” Now , it is a curious fact that you can always curse human nature with impunity ; can malign it , revile it , boot it up and down the decalogue , and you will be warmly praised . “ How true to life ! ” you are told . “ I know some one just like that . ” ( It is always some one else , of course . ) But dare lay hands on the Existing Order — and you 'll find you 've laid your hands on a hornet 's nest . You see , most people do not want anything changed — except possibly the Law of Change . They do not object to finding fault with mankind because “ you can n't change human nature , ” as they are fond of telling you with an interesting air of originality . But laws , customs , and ideals can be changed , can be improved . Therefore they cry : “ Hands off ! How dare you ! ” Man made human institutions , therefore we reverence them . Whereas human nature was merely made by God . So we do n't think so much of it . We are prejudiced , like all creators , in favor of our own creations . After all , there is excellent precedent for such complacency . Even God , we are informed , pronounced his work “ all very good ” and rested on the seventh day . Pretty nearly everything in the play as acted is in the book as published ; but by no means all that is in the book could possibly be enacted on the stage in two hours and a half . One scene , a breakfast scene between John and his wife , has been amplified for acting , but all the other scenes as printed here have been shortened for stage purposes and one or two cut out entirely . The “ set ” was changed to represent the loggia , instead of the terrace , of John 's “ little farm . ” Outdoor scenes are not supposed to be good for comedy . Walls , or a suggestion of them , produce a better psychological effect for the purpose , besides making it possible to speak in quieter , more intimate tones than when the voice spills out into the wings and up into the paint loft .

titlePage.docImprint: Near the end of the play a number of relatives , rich and poor , are supposed to arrive for dinner and for influencing by their presence the recalcitrant couple . That is the way it is printed and that is how it was acted during the first few weeks of theChicagorun . But though the family may have its place in the book , it proved to be an awful nuisance on the stage . No matter how well these minor parts might be acted ( or dressed ) , their sudden irruption during the last and most important moments of the performance distracted the audience 's attention from the principal characters and the main issue . It was not clear who was who . Programmes fluttered ; perplexity was observed .... So we decided that the family must be destroyed . It is always a perplexing problem to devise a substitute for the family .

div.head: ACT I

sp.speaker: ACT I
sp.p: Up from the fragrant garden comes a girl , running . She takes the broad terrace steps two at a stride , laughing , breathless , fleet as a fawn , sweet as a rose . She is hotly pursued by a boy , handsome , ardent , attractively selfish , and just now blindly determined to catch the pretty creature before she gains the protecting shelter of home . She is determined to let him but not to let him know it .... There , she might have darted in through the open door , but it is such a cold , formal entrance ; she pretends to be exhausted , dodges behind a stone tea-table , and , turning , faces him , each panting and laughing excitedly ; she alluring and defiant , he merry and dominant . She is twenty-five and he is a year or two older , but they are both children ; in other words , unmarried .

sp.p: I — er — do .

sp.speaker: REX

sp.speaker: JEAN

sp.speaker: REX
sp.p: Am I sure ! You irresistible little —

sp.p: feminine triumphAnd me “ a penniless orphing ” ?

sp.speaker: REX

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: giving herself to him , head sinks upon his shoulderThen , oh , Rex , love me and be nice to me and — and take me away from all this !

sp.speaker: LUCY comes up from the garden . She is dressed in white with a
sp.p: garden hat , a garden basket filled with flowers in one hand , long scissors in the other . She is JOHN 'S wife , the mistress of the house , sister-in-law to JEAN ; conspicuously a “ sweet ” woman , affectedly so , a contrast with JEAN 'S more modern , less delicate charm . JEAN is frank and brave , LUCY indirect and timid , pretty but fading , forty but fighting it .

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: laughingIt 's all right , Lucy — we 're engaged !

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Well , I should hope so !

div.stage: Shoots a look at JEAN , “ So ? ”

sp.speaker: REX
sp.p: recovering himselfI have often tried to thank you and good old John for letting me come over here so much , but now ! How can I ever thank you ? See-what-I-mean ?

sp.speaker: JEAN

Thank you so much .

div.stage: Alone , they throw off the mask worn before men .

sp.p: Now , deary , tell me all about it . How did it happen ?

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: Oh , I simply followed your advice .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Picked a quarrel with him ?

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: laughingYes . I pretended to believe in woman suffrage !

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Good ! They hate that .

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: I told him all men were bullying brutes !

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: They are ! And then you ran away ?

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: Of course .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: And he after you ?

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: Of course .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: And you let him catch you ?

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: Of cour — well ... he caught me .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: I can guess the rest .

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: Why , it did n't take five minutes .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: And now it 's to last through all eternity .... Is n't love wonderful ?

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: Um-hum . Wonderful .

sp.p: But you do love him , dear , do n't you ?

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Well , I may be old-fashioned , but I do n't think it 's nice to talk this way when you 're just engaged .

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: Here comes your “ sexless freak ” — not with a degree , either .

sp.speaker: With a man !
sp.p: JEAN

div.stage: smiling

p.stage: HELEN , with REX bending toward her eagerly , appears . She is a beautiful woman of twenty-nine , tall , strong , glorious — plenty of old-fashioned charm , despite her new-fashioned ideas . She is dressed in a tennis costume and is swinging a racquet .

sp.speaker: REX
sp.p: But they told me you were going to stay abroad all winter .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: My work , Rex — I had to get back to work .

sp.speaker: REX
sp.p: Work !... You are too good to work .

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: amused , not jealousIs this your high-powered car , Rex ? Have you learned to run it yet ?

sp.speaker: REX
sp.p: startledBut ... well ... you see , I met Helen on the way . See-what-I-mean ?

lg.l: REX
But I had n't seen her for so long . I thought —
wait , I 'll get the car .

div.stage: He hurries off .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: to JEANWhy could n't she have stayed abroad !

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: Helen , do n't talk about your work before Lucy — it shocks her .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Oh , very well ; make it my ‘ career ’ !

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: arm around HELENSssh !— that 's worse .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Helen , dear , I deem it my duty to tell you that you are being talked about .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Lucy , dear , do you always find your true happiness in duty ?

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Well , if you think you are going back to that horrid place again ... after what happened that night ? John wo n't hear of it .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: If the Baker Institute of Medical Experiment is not a respectable place you should make John resign as trustee .

div.stage: She laughs it off .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: John is trustee of — oh , nearly everything . That makes it all the worse . It is n't as if you had to work .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Oh , but John is so rich now , his credit can stand it . And you ought n't to mind ! Why , some of our most fashionable families now contain freaks like me . It 's becoming quite smart , just as in former days one of the sons would go into the Church or the navy .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Well , of course , I am old-fashioned , but going down-town every day with the men ,— it seems so unwomanly .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: But was n't I womanly for years ? Instead of going down-town and working with highbrows , I stayed up-town and played with lowbrows — until I was bored to death .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: sighsYes , that 's what comes of going to college , leaving the home , getting these new ideas . All the same , Helen , the men , really nice men , do n't like it .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Well , you see , I do n't like really nice men , so that makes it agreeable all around .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: If it were only art or music or something feminine , but that awful laboratory ! How can a lady poison poor , innocent little monkeys ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: If I were a lady I 'd dine with monkeys .... Do you know what the word means , Lucy ? In Anglo-Saxon times “ lady ” meant “ one who gives loaves ” ; now , one who takes a loaf .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Very clever , my dear , but some day you 'll be sorry . No man , Helen , likes a woman to have independent views .

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: Helen can afford to have independent views ; she has an independent income — she earns it .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Independent income ! Her salary would n't pay for your hats .

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: All the same , I wish I had gone to college ; I wish I had learned a profession .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: What have these New Women accomplished ? Just one thing : they are destroying chivalry !

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Not entirely , Lucy , not entirely . For instance , I am the best assistant Ernest Hamilton has , but the worst paid ; the others are all men . Hurray for chivalry !

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Well , I 'm just an old-fashioned wife . Woman 's sphere is the home . My husband says so .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: But suppose you have n't any husband ! What can a spinster do in the home ?

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Stay in it — till she gets one ! That 's what the old-fashioned spinster used to do .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: The old-fashioned spinster used to spin .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: At any rate , the old-fashioned spinster did not stay out of her home all night and get herself compromised , talked about , sent abroad ! Or , if she did , she knew enough to remain abroad until the gossip blew over .

div.stage: Lucy turns to leave .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: mischievouslyAh , that wonderful night !LUCY turns back , amazed .The night we discovered the Hamilton antitoxin , the night that made the Baker Institute famous ! And , just think , I had a hand in it , Lucy , a hand in the unwomanly work of saving children 's lives ! But , of course , an old-fashioned spinster would have blushed and said : “ Excuse me , Doctor Hamilton , but we must now let a year 's work go to waste because you are a man and I am a woman , and it 's dark outdoors ! ” ... That 's the way to preserve true chivalry .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: You think we can n't see through all this ? Science — fiddlesticks ! The good-looking young scientist — that 's why you could n't stay abroad . We see it , John sees it , and now every one will see it . Then how will you feel ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Ernest is rather good-looking , is n't he ?

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Do you think your brother will let you marry a mere scientist !... Oh , well , Doctor Hamilton is in love with his work — fortunately .... Besides , he 's a thoroughbred ; he would n't even look at a girl who throws herself at his head .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: So I need n't try any longer ? Too bad .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: losing her temper and goingOh , you New Women are quite superior , are n't you ?... Thank heavens , little Jean did n't elbow her way into men 's affairs ; she had no unwomanly ambitions for a career ! But she is engaged to Rex Baker !

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Jean , is this true ?

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: triumphantlyMarriage is woman 's only true career .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Jean ! You can n't , you wo n't , you must n't marry Rex !

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: flouncing out“ She who will not when she may , ” my dear !

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: avoiding HELEN 'S eyesLucy hears John coming — he 'd take her head off if she were n't there to meet him .HELEN only looks at her .He bullies and browbeats her worse than ever . I can n't stand it here much longer . It 's getting on my nerves .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Jean ! You care for Rex no more than I do .

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: still evasiveJohn 's bringing out Uncle Everett and Cousin Theodore . My dear , the whole family is up in the air about you .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Oh , I can take care of myself , but you !... Jean , you 're not the sort to marry Rex or any other man , unless you simply can n't live without him .

sp.speaker: JEAN

sp.p: But you would n't live on a man you did n't really love !

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: Why not ? Lucy does ; most wives live on men they do n't really love . To stop doing so and get divorced is wrong , you know .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Jean , Jean , poor little Jean !

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: Well , I 'd rather have domestic unhappiness of my own than watch other people 's all my life .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: I do n't like to hurt you , dear , but —Takes JEAN 'S face and raises it .How about that nice boy at the Harvard Law School ?

Law School , Helen .

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: He never asked me to , Helen .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: He would , if you let him .

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: It would n't be fair . It takes so long to get started . Everything costs so much . Why , nowadays , men in the professions , unless they have private means , can n't marry until nearly forty . When Bob is forty I 'll be forty , Helen .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Ah , but when a girl really cares !

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: Helen , do you know ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Never mind about me — you !

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: Oh , we 'll get over it , I suppose .... People do ! Some day , perhaps , he 'll smile and say : “ Just think , I once loved that fat old thing ! ”Suddenly changes to sobbing .Helen ! when Rex caught me and kissed me I shut my eyes and tried to think it was Bob .

sp.p: takes JEAN in her armsYou can n't keep on thinking so , dear .

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: But that is n't the worst ! When he held me fast and I could n't get away , I began ... to forget Bob ... to forget everything ...Breaks off , overcome with shame .But not now , not now ! I trapped him into it ; I trapped him !

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: And I know Rex — he 's a good sport ; he 'll stick to it , if you do , dear — only you wo n't ! You 've caught him by playing on his worst — do n't hold him by playing on his best !

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: But what shall I do ? I 'm nearly twenty-six . I 've got to escape from home in some way .

sp.speaker: HELEN

sp.speaker: REX
sp.p: Ready , Jean ?To HELEN .Lucy and John and your Cousin Theodore are in there having a fine , old-fashioned family fight with the judge .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: With Uncle Everett ? What about ?

sp.p: They shut up when they saw me . All I heard was the parson — “ Marriage is a social institution . ” Grand old row , though .A BUTLER and FOOTMAN appear , wheeling a tea-wagon .Looks as if they were coming out here .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Then I am going in .Detaining JEAN .You will follow my advice ?

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: apart to HELENOh , I do n't know . Soon or late I must follow the only profession I have learned .

div.stage: JEAN leaves with REX . HELEN watches them , sighs , and goes in . The SERVANTS arrange the tea-table and go into the house .

sp.speaker: LUCY comes out , followed by her husband , JOHN , and the JUDGE , who
sp.p: is UNCLE EVERETT , and COUSIN THEODORE .

sp.speaker: JOHN , the masterful type of successful American business man ;
sp.p: well set up , close-cropped mustache , inclined to baldness ; keen eye , vibrant voice , quick movements , quick decisions , quick temper .

sp.speaker: UNCLE EVERETT is a genial satirist with a cynical tolerance of
sp.p: the ways of the world , which he understands , laughs at , and rather likes .

sp.speaker: COUSIN THEODORE , a care-worn rector , who , though he buttons his
sp.p: collar behind , likes those who do n't ; a noble soul , self-sacrificing and sanctified , but he does not obtrude his profession upon others — never talks shop unless asked to do so , and prides himself upon not being a bigot . They are continuing an earnest discussion , with the intimate manner of friendly members of the same family . JOHN , LUCY , and THEODORE deeply concerned ; UNCLE EVERETT detached and amused .

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: But , Uncle Everett , has n't Aunt Julia always been a good wife to you ?

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: Quite so , quite so , a good wife , Theodore , a good wife .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: And a devoted mother to your children , Uncle Everett ?

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: Devoted , Lucy , devoted .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: She has always obeyed you , Uncle Everett .

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: Yes , John — a true , old-fashioned woman .

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: She has been a great help to me in the parish work , Uncle Everett .

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: An earnest worker in the vineyard , Theodore — in fact , I might say , a model female .

sp.speaker: ALL
sp.p: Then why , why do you want a divorce ?

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: Because , damn it , I do n't like her !

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: But think of poor Aunt Julia !

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: But , damn it , she does n't like me .

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: wagging head sadlyAh , yes , I suppose there has been fault on both sides .

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: Not at all ! No fault on either side .... Both patterns of Christian fortitude to the end ! We still are . Just listen to this telegram .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: puzzledFrom Aunt Julia ?

div.stage: Illustration : From a photograph by White Studio .

sp.speaker: ALL : Then why , why do you want a divorce ?
sp.p: JUDGE : Because , damn it , I do n't like her . ]

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: Yes from Aunt Julia in Reno . Not used to travelling without me ; knew I 'd worry . Thoughtful of her , was n't it ?Puts on glasses .A night letter . Much cheaper ; your Aunt Julia was always a frugal wife . Besides , she never could keep within ten words .Reads .“ Arrived safely . Charming rooms with plenty of air and sunlight . Our case docketed for March 15th . Wish you were here to see the women in Divorcee Row — overdressed and underbred . ” Rather neat , eh ? “ Overdressed and underbred . ” “ I should love to hear your comments on the various types . ” Now , is n't that sweet of her ? Well , you know , I always could make her laugh — except when I made her cry . “ Write soon . With love . Julia . ” Nowfolds telegram, is n't that a nice message ? From a wife suing for divorce ? You happily married people could n't beat that .

div.stage: Pats telegram and pockets it tenderly .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: like a practical business manBut if there 's no other woman , no other man — what 's it all about ?

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: She likes her beefsteak well done ; I like mine underdone . She likes one window open — about so muchindicates four inches; I like all the windows open wide ! She likes to stay at home ; I like to travel . She loves the opera and hates the theatre ; I love the theatre and hate the opera .

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: Stop ! are n't you willing to make a few little sacrifices for each other ? Have n't you character enough for that ?

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: We 've been making sacrifices for twenty-five years , a quarter of a century ! Character enough to last us now .... Why , I remember the first dinner we had together after we were pronounced man and wife , with a full choral service and a great many expensive flowers — quite a smart wedding , Lucy , for those simple days . “ Darling , ” I asked my blushing bride , “ do you like tutti-frutti ice-cream ? ” “ I adore it , dearest , ” she murmured . I hated it , but nobly sacrificed myself and gave her tutti-frutti and gained character every evening of our honeymoon ! Then when we got back and began our “ new life ” together in our “ little home , ” my darling gave me tutti-frutti and indigestion once a week until I nearly died !

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: But why did n't you tell her ?

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: I did ; I did . Got chronic dyspepsia and struck ! “ You may adore this stuff , darling , ” I said , “ but I hate it . ” “ So do I , dearest , ” says she . “ Then why in thunder have you had it all these years , sweetheart ? ” “ For your sake , beloved ! ” And that tells the whole story of our married life . We have nothing in common but a love of divorce and a mutual abhorrence of tutti-frutti . “ Two souls with but a single thought , two hearts that beat as one ! ” It has been the dream of our lives to get apart , and each has nobly refrained for the other 's sake . And all in vain !

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Bah ! All a cloak to hide his real motive . And he knows it !

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: after a painful pauseI may as well confess .Looks around to see if overheard . Whispers .For over twenty years I — I have broken my marriage vow !LUCY drops her eyes . THEODORE aghast . JOHN wags head .So has your Aunt Julia !

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: No ! not that !

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: Well , we solemnly promised to love each other until death did us part . We have broken that sacred vow ! I do n't love her ; she does n't love me — not in the least !

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Rot ! A matured , middle-aged man , a distinguished member of the bar — break up his home for that ? Damned rot !

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: Right again , John . That 's not why I 'm breaking up my home . I prefer my club . What does the modern home amount to ? Merely a place to leave your wife .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Of course , it does n't matter about the poor little wife left at home .

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: Wrong , Lucy , it does matter . That 's why I stayed at home and was bored to death with her prattle about clothes and the opera , instead of dining at the club with my intellectual equals , picking up business there , getting rich like John , supplying her with more clothes and a whole box at the opera , like yours , Lucy .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: shoots a glance at her husbandOh , that 's the way you men always talk . It never occurs to you that business , business , business is just as much of a bore to us !

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: Wrong again ! It did occur to me — hence the divorce ! She could n't stand seeing me bored ; I could n't stand seeing her bored . Once we could deceive each other ; but now — too well acquainted ; our happy home — a hollow mockery !

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: You ought to be ashamed ! I love my home !

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: So do I .

div.stage: He glances sternly at LUCY .

sp.speaker: So do I
sp.p: JUDGE All right . Stick to it , if you love it . Only , do n't claim credit for doing what you enjoy . I stuck to my home for a quarter of a century and disliked it the whole time . At last I 'm free to say so . Just think of it , Lucy , free to utter those things about marriage we all know are true but do n't dare say ! Free to be honest , John ! No longer a hypocrite , no longer a liar ! A soul set free , Theodore — two souls , in fact . “ Two souls with but a single thought —— ”

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: Stop ! You have children to consider , not merely your own selfish happiness !

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Yes , think of Tom and little Julia !

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: We did ... for a quarter of a century — sacrificed everything to them , even our self-respect ; but now — what 's the use ? We are childless now . Tom and Julia have both left us for “ little homes ” of their own to love .

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: Ah , but do n't you want them to have the old home to come back to ?

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: “ No place like home ” for children , eh ? You 're right — can n't have too much of it . Most children only have one home . Ours will have two ! When they get bored with one they can try the other .

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: But , seriously , Uncle Everett — “ Whom God hath joined together ! ”

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: clasping JOHN 'S armYes , Uncle Everett , marriages are made in heaven .

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: I see ; quite so ; but your Aunt Julia and I were joined together by a pink parasol made in Paris .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: What rot ! Stop your fooling and speak the truth , man .

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: Just what I 'm doing — that 's why you think I 'm fooling . A very pretty parasol — but it was n't made in heaven . You see , God made poor , dear Julia pale , but on that fatal day , twenty-five years ago , the pink parasol , not God , made her rosy and irresistible . I did the rest — with the aid of a clergyman , whom I tipped even more liberally than the waiter who served us tutti-frutti . Blame me for it , blame her , the parasol , the parson , but do not , my dear Theodore , blame the Deity for our own mistakes . It 's so blasphemous .

div.stage: A pause . LUCY takes place at the tea-table to serve tea .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: And to think we invited you , of all people , here to-day of all days !To JOHN .We must n't let Rex know . The Bakers do n't believe in divorce .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: What 's this ? You do n't mean that Jean ——?

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Yes ! Just in time — before he knew Helen was back .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: jumps upShe 's landed him ! She 's landed him ! We 're marrying into the Baker family ! The Baker family !Shaking hands right and left .Why , she 'll have more money than any of us !... Well , well ! We 'll all have to stand around before little Jean now !... My , my ! Lucy , you 're a wonder ! Those pearls — I 'll buy them ; they 're yours ! Hurray for Lucy !

div.stage: Kisses LUCY .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: feeling her importanceNow , if I could only get Helen out of this awful mess and safely married to some nice man !

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: sipping his teaMeaning one having money ?

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: The Hamiltons are an older family than the Bakers , Lucy , older than our own .

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: Meaning they once had money .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: still pacing to and froWaste a beauty on a bacteriologist ? A crime !

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: See here , John , Ernest Hamilton is the biggest thing you 've got in the Baker Institute ! One of the loveliest fellows in the world , too , and if you expect me — why did you ask us here , anyway ?

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: Far as I can make out , we 're here to help one of John 's sisters marry a man she does n't love and prevent the other from marrying the man she does .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Oh , look here : I 've nothing against young Hamilton .... I like him — proud of all he 's done for the institute . Why , Mr. Baker is tickled to death about the Hamilton antitoxin . But , Theodore , this is a practical world . Your scientific friend gets just two thousand dollars a year !... Lucy , send for Helen .

div.stage: LUCY goes obediently .

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: Well , why not give the young man a raise ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Oh , that 's not a bad salary for scientists , college professors , and that sort of thing . Why , even the head of the institute himself gets less than the superintendent of my mills . No future in science .

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: Perfectly practical , Theodore . The superintendent of John 's mills saves the company thousands of dollars . These bacteriologists merely save the nation thousands of babies . All our laws , written and unwritten , value private property above human life . I 'm a distinguished jurist and I always render my decisions accordingly . I 'd be reversed by the United States Supreme Court if I did n't . We 're all rewarded in inverse ratio to our usefulness to society , Theodore . That 's why “ practical men ” think changes are “ dangerous . ”

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Muck-raker !

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: It 's all on a sliding scale , John . For keeping up the cost of living you and old man Baker get ...Stretches arms out full length .Heaven only knows how much . For saving the Constitution I get ... a good deal .Hands three feet apart .For saving in wages and operating expenses your superintendent gets so much .Hands two feet apart .For saving human life Ernest Hamilton gets that .Hands six inches apart .For saving immortal souls Theodore gets —Holds up two forefingers an inch apart .Now , if any one came along and saved the world ——

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: interruptsThey crucified Him .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Muck-raker , muck-raker .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: returningTried my best , John , but Helen says she prefers to talk with you alone some time .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: furiousShe “ prefers ” ? See here ! Am I master in my own house or not ?

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: But Helen is a guest in it now . No longer under your control , John . She 's the New Woman .

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: John , you can n't stop that girl 's marrying Ernest , if she wants to ; he 's head over heels in love with her .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: What ! We thought he was in love with his work !

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: He thinks there 's no hope for him , poor boy .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: to JOHNAnd she is mad about him !

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: to LUCYAnd he is on the way out here now !

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: What ! He 's coming to see her ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: No , no , thinks she 's still in Paris — so she was when I invited him , damn it — but something had to be done and done delicately . That 's why I invited you two .

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: bursts out laughingBeautiful ! These lovers have n't met for a month , and to-night there 's a moon !

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: also laughsYou may as well give in , John . It 's the simplest solution .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: timidlyYes , John , she 's nearly thirty , and think how she treats all the nice men .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Who 's doing this ? You go tell Helen ... that her Uncle Everett wants to see her !

div.stage: Lucy shrugs , starts reluctantly , and lingers listening .

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: Now , uncle , you have more influence over her than any of us — do n't let her know about ... Aunt Julia . Helen thinks the world of you .

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: Of course not , never let the rising generation suspect the truth about marriage — if you want ‘ em to marry .

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: There are other truths than unpleasant truths , Uncle Everett , other marriages than unhappy marriages .

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: Want me to tell her the truth about your marriage ?

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: at the doorWhy uncle ! Even you must admit that Theodore and Mary are happy .

div.stage: JOHN is too much surprised to notice LUCY 'S presence .

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: Happy ? What 's that got to do with it ? Marriage is a social institution . Theodore said so .... Every time a boy kisses a girl she should first inquire : “ A sacrifice for society ? ” And if he says , “ I want to gain character , sweetheart , ” then — “ Darling , do your duty ! ” and he 'll do it .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Well , Theodore has certainly done his duty by society — six children !

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: Then society has n't done its duty by Theodore — only one salary !

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: The more credit to him ! He and Mary have sacrificed everything to their children and the Church — even health !

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: We do n't need your pity ! We do n't want your praise ! Poverty , suffering , even separation , have only drawn us closer together . We love each other through it all ! Why , in the last letter the doctor let her write she said , she said —Suddenly overcome with emotion , turns abruptly .If you 'll excuse me , Lucy ... Sanitarium ... the telephone .

div.stage: THEODORE goes into the house .

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: Not praise or pity but something more substantial and , by George , I 'll get it for them !

div.stage: Turns to JOHN , who interrupts .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: See the example he sets to society — I honor him for it .

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: Fine ! but that does n't seem to restore Mary 's radiant health , Theodore 's brilliant youth .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Ah , but they have their children — think how they adore those beautiful children !

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: No , do n't think how they adore them , think how they rear those beautiful children — in the streets ; one little daughter dead from contagion ; one son going to the devil from other things picked up in the street ! If marriage is a social institution , look at it socially . Why , a marriage like mine is worth a dozen like theirs — to Society . Look at my well-launched children ; look at my useful career , as a jackal to Big Business ; look at my now perfectly contented spouse !

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: But if you are divorced !

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: Is the object of marriage merely to stay married ?

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: But character , think of the character they have gained .

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: Oh , is it to gain character at the expense of helpless offspring ? Society does n't gain by that — it loses , Lucy , it loses .... But simply because , God bless ‘ em , “ they love each other through it all , ” you sentimental standpatters believe in lying about it , do you ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: bored , whips out pocket check-book and fountain penOh , talk , talk , talk ! Money talks for me .... But they 're both so confoundedly proud !

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: Go on , write that check !JOHN writes .They must sacrifice their pride , John . Nothing else left to sacrifice , I 'm afraid .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Well , you get this to them somehow .

div.stage: Hands check to JUDGE .

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: Aha ! Talk did it .... Five thousand ? Generous John !

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: impatientlyNever mind about me . That problem is all settled ; now about Helen .... Lucy ! I thought I told you ——

div.stage: LUCY , in a guilty hurry , escapes into the house .

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: John , charity never settles problems ; it perpetuates them . You can n't cure social defects by individual treatment .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: more impatientlyDoes talk settle anything ?

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: Everything . We may even settle the marriage problem if we talk honestly .THEODORE returns from telephoning to the sanitarium .Theodore , it 's all right ! John honestly believes in setting an example to society ! Crazy to have his sisters go and do likewise !

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: Splendid , John ! I knew you 'd see it — an ideal match .

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: overriding JOHNRight , Theodore , ideal . This scientific suitor will shower everything upon her John honors and admires : A host of servants — I mean sacrifices ; carriages and motors — I mean character and morals ; just what her brother advocates in Sunday-school — for others . An ideal marriage .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: hands in pocketsYou think you 're awfully funny , do n't you ? Humph ! I do more for the Church , for education , art , science than all the rest of the family combined . Incidentally , I 'm not divorced .... But this is a practical world , Theodore , I 've got to protect my own .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: returningHelen will be here in a minute .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: suddenly getting an ideaAh ! I have it ! I know how to keep them apart !

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: Be careful , John — these two love each other .

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: Yes , young people still fall in love . Whether we make it hard or easy for them — they will do it . But , mark my words , unless we reform marriage , there is going to be a sympathetic strike against it — as there is already against having children . Instead of making it harder to get apart , we 've got to make it easier to stay together . Otherwise the ancient bluff will soon be called !

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Sssh ! Here she comes .

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: Please do n't talk this way before her .

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: All right , I 'm not divorced yet ,... still in the conspiracy of silence .

div.stage: HELEN appears at the door . A sudden silence .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: kissing THEODORE and JUDGE affectionatelyI 'm so sorry to hear about dear Mary .To JUDGE .But why did n't Aunt Julia come ? Is she ill , too ?

div.stage: Slight panic in the family party .

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: She 's gone to Re-Re-Rio Janeiro — I mean to Santa Barbara — wants a complete change — The Rest Cure .To THEODORE apart .Lie number one .

div.stage: Another silence . LUCY makes tea for HELEN .

lg.l: THEODORE
Go on with what ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: stirring teaYour discussion of marriage .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: How did you know ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Oh , it 's in the air . Everybody 's talking about it nowadays .

div.stage: She sips tea , and the others look conscious .

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: My dear , marriage is woman 's only true career .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: raising her shield of flippancySo Lucy tells me , Cousin Theodore . But a woman cannot pursue her career , she must be pursued by it ; otherwise she is unwomanly .

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: Ahem . As we passed through the library a while ago , I think I saw your little sister being pursued by her career .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Yes , uncle , but Jean is a true woman . I 'm only a New Woman .

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: All the same , you 'll be an old woman some day — if you do n't watch out .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Ah , yes , my life 's a failure . I have n't trapped a man into a contract to support me .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: picks up knitting bag and does her best to look like “ just an old-fashioned wife ”You ought to be ashamed ! Making marriage so mercenary . Helen , dear , have n't you New Women any sentiment ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Enough sentiment not to make a mercenary marriage , Lucy , dear .

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: Ahem ! And what kind of a marriage do you expect to make ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Not any , thank you , uncle .

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: What ! You do n't believe in holy matrimony ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Only as a last extremity , uncle , like unholy divorce .

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: jumpsWhat do you know about that ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: I know all about it !Others jump .I have been reading up on the subject .

div.stage: All relax , relieved , but now gather about the young woman .

sp.speaker: THEODORE }
sp.p: } Come now , simply because many young people } rush into marriage without thinking — } } } LUCY }Together} Simply because these New Women — } } } JOHN } } Simply because one marriage in a } thousand ends in divorce — }

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Wait !... One in a thousand ? Dear me , what an idealist you are , John ! In America , one marriage in every eleven now ends in divorce . And yet you wonder why I hesitate .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: One in eleven — rot !To JUDGE .All this muck-raking should be suppressed by the Government . “ One in eleven ! ” Bah !

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: demurelyThe Government 's own statistics , John .

div.stage: They all turn to the JUDGE for denial , but he nods confirmation , with a complacent smile , murmuring : “ Two souls with but a single thought . ”

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: sweetly knittingWell , I may be old-fashioned , but it seems to me that nice girls should n't think of such things .... Their husbands will tell them all they ought to know about marriage — after they 're married .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Ah , I see . Nice girls must n't think until after they rush in , but they must n't rush in until after they think . You married people make it all so simple for us .

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: Right ! The way to cure all evil is for nice people to close their minds and mouths to it . It 's “ unpleasant ” for a pure mind , and it “ leaves a bad taste in the mouth . ” So there you are , my dear .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: coming in strongOh , talk , talk , talk ! I 've had enough . See here , young lady , I offered to pay all your expenses abroad for a year . You did n't seem to appreciate it — well , the trustees of the institute are now to give Doctor Hamilton a year abroad . How do you like that ?

div.stage: All turn and look at HELEN .

lg.l: Splendid ! Just what he needs ! Doctor Metchnikoff told me in Paris that
America always kills its big men with routine . When do we start ?

div.stage: She tries to look very businesslike .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: springing to his feet“ We ! ” Do you think you are going ?

lg.l: Of course ! I 'm his assistant — quite indispensable to him ....
Oh , well , if you do n't believe me , ask him !

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: pacing to and froWhat next ! Paris ! Alone , with a man !— Here 's where I call a halt !

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: But if my work calls me , I do n't really see what you have to say about it , John .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Better not defy me , Helen .

div.stage: He scowls .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Better not bully me , John .

div.stage: She smiles .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I am your brother .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: But not my owner !Then , instead of defiance , she turns with animated interest to the others .You know , all women used to be owned by men . Formerly they ruled us by physical force — now by financial force .... But at last they are to lose even that hold upon us — poor dears !

div.stage: Pats JOHN 'S shoulder playfully .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: amused , but seriousThat 's all right in theory , but this is a practical world . My pull got you into the institute ; my pull can get you out . You give up this wild idea or give up your job !

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: delightedWhat did I tell you ? Financial force ! They still try it , you see .To JOHN .What if I refused to give up either , John ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: emphaticThen as a trustee of the institute I ask for your resignation — right here and now !Turns away .I guess that will hold her at home a while .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: I simply must go to Paris now . I 've nothing else to do !

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: with a confident smileYou will , eh ? Who 'll pay your expenses this time ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: matter of factDoctor Hamilton .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Helen ! please ! You ought n't to say such things even in joke .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: He 'll take me along as his private secretary , if I ask him .

div.stage: A pause . The others look at one another helplessly .

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: John , she 's got you . You might as well quit .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Nonsense . I have just begun . You 'll see .

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: If you 're so independent , my dear , why do n't you marry your scientist and be done with it ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: resents the intrusion but hides her feelingsCan you keep a secret ?They all seem to think they can and gather near .He has never asked me !

div.stage: The family seems annoyed .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: with match-making ardorNo wonder , dear , he has never seen you except in that awful apron . But those stunning dinner gowns John bought you in Paris ! My dear , in evening dress you are quite irresistible !

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: apart to THEODOREIrresistible ? Pink parasols . What a system !

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: But you see , I do n't want him to ask me . I 've had all I could do to keep him from it .

div.stage: The family seems perplexed .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: She 's got some sense left .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: But suppose he did ask you , dear ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Why , I 'd simply refer the matter to John , of course . If John said , “ Love him , ” I 'd love him ; if John said , “ Do n't love him , ” I 'd turn it off like electric light .

div.stage: The family is becoming exasperated .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: insinuatingOh , you can n't deceive us . We know how much you admire him , Helen .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Oh , no you do n't !The family is amazed .Not even he does . Did you ever hear how he risked his life in battle down in Cuba ? Why , he 's a perfect hero of romance !

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: muttersNever even saw a war — mollycoddle germ killer !

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Not in the war with Spain — the war against yellow fever , John .... No drums to make him brave , no correspondents to make him famous — he merely rolled up his sleeve and let an innocent-looking mosquito bite him . Then took notes on his symptoms till he became delirious .... He happened to be among those who recovered .

div.stage: The family is impressed .

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: Old-fashioned maidens used to marry their heroes , Helen .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: arising , brisklyBut this new-fashioned hero gets only two thousand dollars a year , Theodore .

div.stage: She turns to escape .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: noddingI told you she had sense .

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: Helen ! You selfish , too ? Why , Mary and I married on half that , did n't we , John ?

div.stage: He looks around . The family looks away .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: with unintended emphasisDoctor Hamilton needs every cent of that enormous salary — books , travel , scientific conferences — all the advantages he simply must have if he 's to keep at the top and do his best work for the world . The most selfish thing a girl can do is to marry a poor man .

div.stage: With that she hurries up the steps .

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: following herAll the same , deep down under it all , she has a true woman 's yearning for a home to care for and a mate to love .She is silently crying .Why , Helen , dear , what 's the matter ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: hiding her emotionOh , why can n't they let me alone ! They make what ought to be the holiest and most beautiful thing in life the most horrible and dishonest . They make me hate marriage — hate it !

div.stage: Unseen by HELEN , the BUTLER steps out .

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: patting her shoulderJust you wait till the right one comes along .

sp.speaker: BUTLER
sp.p: to LUCYDoctor Hamilton has come , ma'am .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Show Doctor Hamilton out .

div.stage: The BUTLER goes .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: A plot to entrap him !Running to and fro wildly .But it 's no use ! I 'm going ... until he 's gone !

div.stage: HELEN runs into the garden .

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: Fighting hard , poor child .

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: But what 'll we do ?

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: Do n't worry — she can n't stay away — the sweet thing !

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Now listen , we must all jolly him up — he 'll be shy in these surroundings .

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: Going to surrender , John ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: What I am going to do requires finesse .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: in a flutter , seeing HAMILTON approachOh , dear ! how does one talk to highbrows ?

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: Talk to him about himself ! Highbrows , lowbrows , all men love it .

div.stage: ERNEST HAMILTON , discoverer of the Hamilton antitoxin , is a fine-looking fellow of about thirty-five , without the spectacles or absent-mindedness somehow expected of scientific genius . He talks little but very rapidly and sees everything . It does not occur to him to be shy or embarrassed “ in these surroundings ” — not because he is habituated to so much luxury , on three thousand a year , nor because he despises it ; he likes it ; but he likes other things even more . That is why he works for two thousand a year , instead of working for fat , fashionable fees in private practice .

sp.speaker: JOHN meets his distinguished guest at the door — effusively , yet
sp.p: with that smiling condescension which wealthy trustees sometimes show to “ scientists , college professors , and that sort of thing . ”

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Ah , Doctor Hamilton ! Delighted to see you on my little farm at last . Out here I 'm just a plain , old-fashioned farmer .

div.stage: ERNEST glances about at the magnificence and smiles imperceptibly . He makes no audible replies to the glad welcome , but bows urbanely , master of himself and the situation .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Doctor Hamilton ! So good of you to come .

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: How are you , Ernest ? Glad to see you .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: I do n't think you 've met our uncle , Judge Grey .

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: humorously adopting their mannerCharmed ! I 've heard so much about you !— from my niece .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: to ERNEST 'S rescue , like a tactful hostessA cup of tea , Doctor Hamilton ?

p.stage: unperturbed by the reference to HELEN

sp.speaker: Thanks
sp.p: JOHNwhile LUCY makes tea . Trustee mannerI have often desired to express my admiration of your heroism in the war against yellow fever in er — ah — Cuba , when you let an innocent-looking mosquito bite you ——

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: nodding and poising sugar-tongsAnd then took notes on your symptoms till you became delirious !

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: No sugar , thanks .

div.stage: He looks from one to another with considerable interest .

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: No drums to make you famous , no war correspondents to make you brave — I mean the other way round .

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: to LUCY poising cream pitcherNo cream , please .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Senator Root says this one triumph alone saves twenty million dollars a year to the business interests of the United States ! I call that true patriotism .

p.stage: with a nod of assent to LUCY

sp.speaker: Lemon
sp.p: THEODOREwith sincerityGeneral Wood says it saves more human lives a year than were lost in the whole Spanish War ! I call it service .

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: Colonel Goethals says the Panama Canal could not have been built if it had n't been for you self-sacrificing scientists . Not only that , but you have abolished forever from the United States a scourge which for more than a century had through periodic outbreaks spread terror , devastation , and death .

div.stage: A pause .

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: bored , but trying to hide itThe ones who deserve your praise are the four who died to prove that theory ....He smiles .Of course , you all know their names ....He looks at JOHN , who looks at JUDGE , who looks at LUCY , who looks at THEODORE . He takes up his cup .Delicious tea .

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: Ah , but they did n't do it for fame , for money — that 's the beauty of the sacrifice .

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: with a smileQuite so .... That 's what Congress told us when we suggested a pension for the widow of the first victim .

sp.speaker: ALL
sp.p: What ! Did Congress refuse the pension ?

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: finishes his teaThey finally voted the sum of seventeen dollars a month for the widow and no less than two dollars a month extra for each of his children ....

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Is that all ?

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: No .... We pestered Congress to death until , a few years ago , they replaced the pension with an annuity of one hundred and twenty-five dollars a month — though some of them said it was a very bad precedent to establish .Returns cup to LUCY .No more , thanks , delicious .

div.stage: And turns to admire the wide-sweeping view of the farm , hands in pockets .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: after a pauseWell , I think our scientists might well be called philanthropists .

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: Hardly ! You see , every one knows the names of philanthropists .... Better let it go at “ scientists . ”

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: He 's right . Philanthropists do n't give their lives , they give their names — have ‘ em carved in stone over their institutes and libraries .

div.stage: JOHN approaches and joins his guest .

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: Charming little farm you have here .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Doctor Hamilton , America kills its big men with routine . You are too valuable to the nation to lose — the trustees think you need a year abroad .

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: That 's strange , I came out here to suggest that very thing .... Somebody has been saying kind things about me in Paris . Just had a letter from the great Metchnikoff — wants me to come over and work in the Pasteur ! Chance of a lifetime !... You did n't have to jolly me up to consent to that !

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: pacing terrace with his guest , arm in armBy the by , my sister is rather keen on science .

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: Best assistant I ever had . You can pile an awful lot of routine on a woman . The female of the species is more faithful than the male .... She 's over there already . We can get right to work .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: She 'll be back before you start .

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: stops shortI did n't know that .... Well , what is it ?

div.stage: JOHN hesitates , turns to the family , all watching with breathless interest .

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: Do n't you see , old chap , under the circumstances it would hardly do for her to go back to Paris with you .

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: Why not ?

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: You 're a man .

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: smilingYou mean I 'm dangerous ?

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: But she 's a woman .

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: They mean she 's dangerous .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: My dear fellow , we are going to ask you quite frankly to decline to take her .

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: looks about at the circle of anxious faces . He wont let them read himSo that 's it , eh ?... But it 's the chance of a lifetime for her , too . She needs it more than I do . She 's had so little chance to do original work .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: But she 's a woman .

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: Just what has that to do with it ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Everything . We have the highest respect for you , Doctor Hamilton , but also ... one must respect the opinions of the world , you know .

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: thinks it overThat 's right . One must . I forgot to think of that .... It 's curious , but when working with women of ability one learns to respect them so much that one quite loses the habit of insulting them . Too bad how new conditions spoil fine old customs .... Suppose you let her go and let me stay . I can find plenty to do here , I fancy .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I fear it would offend our generous benefactor , Mr. Baker . He has set his heart on your going abroad , meeting other big men , getting new ideas for our great humanitarian work .The family exchange glances while JOHN lies on .Besides , my sister would only go to accommodate you . She particularly desires to stay here this winter . That 's why she is returning so soon , you see .

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: believes itOh , I see .... I 'm sure I have no desire to drag her over with me ....Smiles at himself .I rather thought the opportunity to continue our experiments together ... but that 's all right .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Then it 's all settled — you agree to go alone ?

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: a slight pauseYes , alone . It 's quite settled .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: How soon could you start ?

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: absentlyHow soon ? Why , just as soon as I get some one to run my department .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Could my sister run it ?

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: smilesCould she run it ? It can n't run without her ! She 's as systematic asto LUCY— as a good housekeeper .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: with a satisfied look at the othersThen that 's all fixed ! She 'll stay when I tell her that you want her to . Could you arrange to start at once ?

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: hesitatesBy leaving here to-night , I could .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: with a triumphant look at the familyThen I 'll telephone for your passage — I have a pull with all the steamship lines .Going .Of course I hate to cut short your week-end , but I do n't want to spoil any scientific careers .

div.stage: JOHN hurries in to telephone . ERNEST starts too , as if to stop him but restrains the impulse . He stands alone by the door gazing out over the landscape while LUCY , THEODORE , and the JUDGE discuss him in low tones by the tea-table .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Ca n't you see , you stupid men ! He 's crazy about her — but thinks there 's no hope .

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: When she finds he 's leaving for a year ... she 'll change her mind about marriage !

div.stage: ERNEST comes back to earth and to the house-party .

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: to ERNEST , joining themAhem ! We were just discussing the marriage danger — I mean the marriage problem .

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: with a smileGo right on — do n't mind me .

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: old-friend mannerSee here ! When are you ever going to marry ?

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: modern bachelor 's laughWhen am I ever going to get more than two thousand a year ?

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: Bah ! what has money got to do with it ! Just you wait till the right one comes along .

div.stage: HELEN comes along , stealing up the steps from the garden on tiptoe with the grave , absorbed look of a hunter stalking game . She catches sight of the man she wants and stops short , as motionless as if frozen . But not so ! Her lovely hands were poised ; one of them now goes to her bosom and presses there . There is nothing icy about this New Woman now .

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: as unconscious of danger as a mountain-lion on an inaccessible height , smiles easily at his sentimental old friend THEODOREHow do you know “ the right one ” has n't come already ?

div.stage: THEODORE catches sight of HELEN . She shakes her head in silent pleading , taps a finger on her lips , and in a panic flees noiselessly across toward the door .

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: suppressing a laughThen do n't let her go by !

div.stage: HELEN stops at the door and makes a face at THEODORE .

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: affecting indifferenceOh , I could n't stop her , even if I wanted to .

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: turning to wink at HELENHow do you know ? Did you ever ask her ?

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: To marry me ? Oh , no ! She has n't any money .

lg.l: Money ! You would n't marry for money !

div.stage: HELEN draws near to hear the answer .

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: You do n't suppose I 'd marry a woman who had n't any ? Most selfish thing a poor man can do .

div.stage: HELEN is interested .

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: Oh , fiddlesticks ! You modern young people —

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: interruptsMake her a sort of superior servant in an inferior home — not that girl !

div.stage: HELEN is pleased .

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: Feministic nonsense ! The old-fashioned womanly woman ——

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: Sentimental twaddle ! What makes it more “ womanly ” to do menial work for men than intellectual work with them ?

div.stage: HELEN delighted , applauds noiselessly .

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: All the same , I 'll bet you would n't let a little thing like that stand in your way if you really cared for a woman enough to marry her .

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: benign and secureBut , as it happens , I do n't . Nothing could induce me to marry .

div.stage: HELEN raises her chin , her eyes glitter dangerously .

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: So you are going to run away to Europe like a coward ?

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: smiles patronizinglyTheodore , you are such an incorrigible idealist ! I have nothing to be afraid of — I simply do not care to marry !

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: That 's just what I said !

div.stage: All turn and behold HELEN .

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: My heavens !

div.stage: He steps back like a coward .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: But I agree with you perfectly .She holds out her hand to him .I was so afraid you believed in marriage .

div.stage: He rushes to her eagerly .

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: as the lovers shake handsYou wronged him . Apologize .

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: Why — why — all this time , I thought you had the usual attitude .

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: Wronged her . Both apologize .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Why did n't you ever tell me you had such enlightened views ?

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: Why did n't you ever tell me ?

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: Each understands the other now . Everything lovely !

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Think of the discussions we might have had !

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: Not too late yet . Julia and I had discussions for a quarter of a century .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Do n't think I had any hand in this .Laughs .I was going to warn you , but now — it is unnecessary now .

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: Warn me ? What do you mean ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Ca n't you see ? It was all a plot !LUCY draws near noiselessly .A plot to entrap you in marriage ! They had about given me up as a bad job . You were my last hope . They were going to throw me at your head .Louder but without turning .Were n't you , Lucy dear ?

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: caught listening , turns abruptly to the othersThese New Women are utterly shameless .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: to ERNESTThese old-fashioned women are utterly shameless . After a decent interval , they will all with one accord make excuses to leave us here alone , so that I can —she comes nearerensnare you !ERNEST laughs nervously .Lucy is going to say —imitates LUCY 'S sweet tones“ If you 'll excuse me , I always take forty winks before dressing . ” Dressing is the hardest work Lucy has to do . Cousin Theodore will find that he must write to his wife , and Uncle Everett will feel a yearning for the billiard room .ERNEST is nodding and chuckling .They 're hanging on longer than usual to-day , and I simply must have a talk with you .

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: Our shop-talk would scandalize ‘ em !

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Wait , I 'll get rid of them !

div.stage: She sits and begins to make tea .

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: I 've had my tea , thanks .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Stupid ! Sit down .Indicates a chair close to hers . He takes it cautiously .We 'll have a little fun with them in a minute .

div.stage: She is busy now making tea .

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: to LUCY and the JUDGE apartYou may be right , Uncle Everett , but upon my word it is the strangest courtship I ever witnessed .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: They ought to be spanked .

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: Do n't worry , old Mother Nature will attend to that .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Well , I may be old-fashioned , but ——

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: interruptingBut this is merely a new fashion , my dear Lucy . Nature her ancient custom holds , let science say what it will .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: handing cup to ERNEST with a glance at the othersNow , then , be attentive to me .He leans toward her rather shyly , abashed by her nearness . She makes eyes at him reproachfully .Oh , can n't you be more attentive than that ?She acts like a coquette and he looks into her beautiful eyes and while he is doing so she says with a fascinating drawlNow tell me a-all about anterior poliomyelitis !

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: suddenly taken aback , he laughsNothing doing since you left .

div.stage: And bends close to explain .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: If you 'll excuse me , Doctor Hamilton , I always take forty winks before dressing . We dine at eight .

div.stage: Going , she signals to the others . ERNEST and HELEN exchange smiles .

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: laughing , to LUCYSs't ! Do n't tell John what 's going on ! Keep him busy telephoning .LUCY nods excitedly and almost runs to obey the Church .Helen , if you and Ernest will excuse me , I really must write to Mary .

div.stage: Their shoulders are close together and they seem too absorbed to reply . THEODORE smiles down upon them and signals the JUDGE to come along . The JUDGE , however , shakes his head but waves THEODORE into the house . Uncle Everett looks at the lovers with quizzical interest . He draws near and eavesdrops shamelessly .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: You ought n't to have dropped the polio experiments .

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: You ought n't to have dropped me — right in the midst of the experiments . Those agar plates you were incubating dried up and spoiled . You played the very devil with my data .

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: God bless my soul ! what are we coming to ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: without turningIt 's perfectly proper for your little ears , uncle , only you can n't understand a word of it . Wo n't any one play billiards with you ?

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: But I 'm fascinated . It 's so idyllic . Makes me feel young again .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: to ERNESTOh , you have plenty of men assistants who can estimate antitoxin units .

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: Men assistants lose interest . They are all so confoundedly ambitious to do original work . Why is it women can stand day after day of monotonous detail better than men ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Because men always made them tend the home !

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: Ah , nothing like a good old-fashioned love scene — in the scientific spirit .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Uncle , dear ! Ca n't you see that he is paying me wonderful compliments ? Have n't you any tact ? Go and play Canfield in the library .

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: lighting cigarVery well , I 'll leave you to your own devices — and may God , your God , have mercy on your scientific souls .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: with sudden animation and camaraderie , thinking they are aloneNow I must tell you what Doctor Metchnikoff said about you and your future !

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: Sst !HELEN and ERNEST turn .My children —Pause — raises his hand .Do n't forget the scientific spirit !

div.stage: The JUDGE saunters off into the garden , smoking .

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: How did you ever meet Metchnikoff ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: chaffingI had worked under Hamilton ! They all wanted to meet me .

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: with an unmistakable lookU 'm ... was that why ?Fleeing danger .Did n't you let them know your part in that discovery ? Why , if it had n't been for you , I should never have stumbled upon the thing at all .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Oh , I know my place too well for that ! Talk about artistic temperament , you scientists are worse than prima donnas .

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: takes printers ’ proofs out of pocket , hands them to her in silenceSome proofs of a monograph I was correcting on the train . Mind hammering those loose sentences of mine into decent English ? You can write — I can n't .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: reading innocently“ Recent Experiments in Anterior Poliomyelitis by Ernest Hamilton , M. D ., Ph. D ., and Helen ” — what ! why , you 've put my name with yours !

div.stage: Much excited and delighted .

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: Well , if you object — like a prima donna ——

div.stage: Takes out pencil to mark on proof .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: snatching proofs awayObject ? Why , this makes my reputation in the scientific world .

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: Well , did n't you make mine ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: still glowing with pride , but touched by his unexpected generosityYou can n't imagine what this means to me . It 's so hard for a woman to get any recognition . Most men have but one use for us . If we get interested in anything but them it is “ unwomanly ” — they call it “ a fad . ” But they 've got to take me seriously now . My name with Ernest Hamilton 's !

div.stage: Points to her name and swaggers back and forth .

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: banteringBut then , you see , you are a very exceptional woman . Why , you have a mind like a man .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Like a man ?Coming close to him , tempting him .If you had a mind like a woman you would know better than to say that to me !

div.stage: Re-enter JUDGE from garden . He smiles and glances at them . The lovers keep quiet as he crosses to the door . Then they look at each other and smile . JUDGE has gone into the house . It is nearly dark . The moon is rising .

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: raises eyebrowsThey all take for granted that I want to make love to you .

div.stage: Smiles but avoids her eyes .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: avoids hisWell , you took for granted that I wanted you to !... You are about the most conceited man I ever knew .

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: How can I help it when you admire me so ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: I ? Admire you ?

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: You 're always telling me what great things I 'm going to do — stimulating me , pushing me along . Why , after you left , everything went slump . Tell me , why did you leave ? Was I rude to you ? Did I hurt your feelings ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Not in the least . It was entirely out of respect for your feelings .

lg.l: My feelings ?
Oh , I see . You got it into your head that
I wanted to marry you !

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Men sometimes do .

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: looks awayI suppose they do .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: It 's been known to happen .

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: Talk about conceit ! Well , you need n't be afraid ! I 'll never ask you to marry me .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: turns and looks at him a momentYou can n't imagine what a weight this takes off my mind .

div.stage: She looks away and sighs .

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: enthusiasticallyYes ! I feel as if a veil between us had been lifted .

div.stage: He looks away and sighs too . Some one begins “ Tristan and Isolde ” on the piano within . The moon is up .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: after a pauseSuppose we talk about — our work .

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: Yes ! Our work . Let 's drop the other subject . Look at the moon !

div.stage: Music and the moonlight flooding them .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Seriously , you promise never to mention the subject again ?

div.stage: She keeps her eyes averted .

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: I promise .

div.stage: He keeps his eyes averted .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: turning to him with a sudden change to girlish enthusiasmThen I 'll go to Paris with you !

lg.l: HELEN
Why , Doctor Metchnikoff — he promised me he would invite you .

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: Yes , but —

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Do n't miss the chance of a lifetime !

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: No , but you — you can n't come !

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: simplyIf you need me I can , and you just said ——

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: But you must n't come to Paris with me !

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Do n't you want me with you ?

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: You are to stay at home and run the department for me .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: stepping backDo n't you want me with you ?

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: stepping forward , with his heart in voiceDo I want you !Stops .But I am a man — you are a woman .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: What of it ? Are you one of those small men who care what people say ? No ! That 's not your reason !She sees that it is not .What is it ? You must tell me .

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: hesitatesIt 's only for your sake .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: with feelingThink of all I 've done for your sake . You would n't be going yourself but for me ! I was the one to see you needed it , I proposed it to Metchnikoff — I urged him — made him ask you — for your sake ! And now am I to be left at home like a child because you do n't care to be embarrassed with me ?

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: Oh , please ! This is so unfair . But I simply can n't take you now .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: with growing scornOh ! You are all alike . You pile work upon me until I nearly drop , you play upon my interest , my sympathy — you get all you can out of me — my youth , my strength , my best ! And then , just as I , too , have a chance to arrive in my profession , you , of all men , throw me over ! I hate men . I hate you !

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: And I love you !

div.stage: They stare at each other in silence , the moonlight flooding HELEN 'S face , the music coming clear .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: in an awed whisper , stepping back slowlyI 've done it ! I 've done it ! I knew I 'd do it !

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: No . I did it . Forgive me . I had to do it .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Oh , and this spoils everything !

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: comes closerNo ! It glorifies everything !He breaks loose .I have loved you from the first day you came and looked up at me for orders . I did n't want you there ; I did n't want any woman there . I tried to tire you out with overwork but could n't . I tried to drive you out by rudeness , but you stayed . And that made me love you more . Oh , I love you ! I love you ! I love you !

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Do n't ; oh , do n't love me !

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: still closerWhy , I never knew there could be women like you . I thought women were merely something to be wanted and worshipped , petted and patronized . But now — why , I love everything about you : your wonderful , brave eyes that face the naked facts of life and are not ashamed ; those beautiful hands that toiled so long , so well , so close to mine and not afraid , not afraid !

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: You must n't ! I am afraid now ! I made you say it .Smiling and crying .I have always wanted to make you say it . I have always sworn you should n't .

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: painedBecause you cannot care enough ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Enough ?... Too much .

p.stage: He takes her in his arms , a silent embrace with only the bland blase moon looking on .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: It is because I love you that I did n't want you to say it — only I did . It is because I love you that I went abroad — to stay , only I could n't ! I could n't stay away !She holds his face in her hands .Oh , do you know how I love you ? No !... you 're only a man !

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: kissing her rapturouslyEvery day there in the laboratory , when you in your apron — that dear apron which I stole from your locker when you left me — when you asked for orders — did you know that I wanted to say : “ Love me ” ! Every day when you took up your work , did you never guess that I wanted to take you up in my arms ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: smiling up into his faceWhy did n't you ?

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: Thank God I did n't ! For while we worked there together I came to know you as few men ever know the women they desire . Woman can be more than sex , as man is more than sex . And all this makes man and woman not less but more overwhelmingly desirable and necessary to each other , and makes both things last — not for a few years , but forever !

div.stage: Sound of voices approaching from the garden . The lovers separate . It is JEAN and REX , REX laughing , JEAN dodging until caught and kissed .

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: No , no — it 's time to dress .... Be good , Rex — do n't !

div.stage: Without seeing HELEN and ERNEST , they disappear into the house . HELEN is suddenly changed , as if awakened from a spell of enchantment .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: What have we done ! This is all moonlight and madness . To-morrow comes the clear light of day .

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: Ah , but we 'll love each other to-morrow !

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: But we cannot marry — then or any other to-morrow .

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: Ca n't ? What nonsense !

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: shaking her head and restraining himI have slaved for you all these months — not because I wanted to win you from your work but to help you in it . And now — after all — shall I destroy you ? No ! No !

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: I love you — you love me — nothing else matters .

sp.speaker: HELEN
