sp.p: Everything else matters . I 'm not a little debutante to be persuaded that I am needed because I am wanted ! I have n't played with you ; I have worked with you , and I know ! Think of Theodore ! Think of Lucy ! And now poor little Jean . Marry you ? Never !

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: You mean your career ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: with supreme scornMy career ? No ! yours — always yours !

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: with the same scorn and a snap of the fingersThen that for my career . I 'll go back into private practice and make a million .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: That 's just what I said you 'd do . Just what you must not do ! Your work is needed by the world .

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: wooingYou are my world and I need you .... But there is no love without marriage , no marriage without money .... We can take it or leave it . Can we leave it ? No ! I can n't — you can n't ! Come !She steps back slowly .Why should we sacrifice the best ! Come !

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: So this is what marriage means ! Then I cannot marry you , Ernest !

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: You cannot do without me , Helen !Holds out his arms .Come ! You have been in my arms once . You and I can never forget that now . We can never go back now . It 's all — or nothing now . Come !She is struggling against her passion . He stands still , with arms held out .I shall not woo you against your will , but you are coming to me ! Because , by all the powers of earth and heaven , you are mine and I am yours ! Come !

div.stage: Like a homing pigeon she darts into his arms with a gasp of joy . A rapturous embrace in silence with the moonlight streaming down upon them . The music has stopped .

sp.speaker: JOHN , dressed for dinner , strolls out upon the terrace . He stops
sp.p: abruptly upon discovering them . The lovers are too absorbed to be aware of his presence .

div.head: ACT II

stage.stage: It is the next morning , Sunday .
It appears that at JOHN 'S country place they have breakfast at small tables out upon the broad , shaded terrace overlooking the glorious view of his little farm .

sp.speaker: ERNEST and THEODORE , the scientist and the clergyman , are
sp.p: breakfasting together . The others are either breakfasting in their rooms or are not yet down , it being Sunday . The man of God is enjoying his material blessings heartily . Also he seems to be enjoying his view of the man of science , who eats little and says less .

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: with coffee-cup poisedWhat 's the matter with your appetite this morning , Ernest ?ERNEST , gazing up at one of the second-story windows , does not hear . The door opens . He starts . Then , seeing it 's only a servant with food , he sighs .Expecting something ? The codfish balls ? Well , here they are .ERNEST refuses the proffered codfish balls , scowls , brings out cigar case , lights cigar , looks at watch , and fidgets .Oh , I know — you 're crazy to go with me — to church !ERNEST does n't hear . Creates a cloud of smoke .Their regular rector is ill . So I agreed to take the service this morning .... Always the way when off for a rest ... is n't it ?No answer . THEODORE gets up , walks around the table , and shouts in ERNEST 'S face .Is n't it ?

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: startledI beg your pardon ?

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: laughs , ERNEST wondering what 's the jokeOh , you 're hopeless !Going .I can n't stand people who talk so much at breakfast .

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: suddenly wakes upWait a minute . Sit down . Have a cigar . Let 's talk about God .THEODORE stops smiling .But I mean it . I 'd like to have a religion myself .

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: I had an idea you took no stock in religion .

div.stage: Takes the cigar . ERNEST holds a match for him .

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: enthusiasticallyJust what I thought , until ... well , I 've made a discovery , a great discovery !

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: A scientific discovery ?

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: with a wave of the handIt makes all science look like a ... mere machine .

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: Well , if you feel so strongly about it ... better come to church after all !

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: I 'm not talking about the Church — I 'm talking about religion .

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: You 're not talking about religion ; you 're talking about — love .

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: quietlyCertainly ; the same thing , is n't it ? I 'm talking about the divine fire that glorifies life and perpetuates it — the one eternal thing we mortals share with God .... If that is n't religious , what is ?THEODORE smiles indulgently .Tell me , Theodore — you know I was n't allowed to go to church when young , and since then I 've always worked on the holy Sabbath day , like yourself — does the Church still let innocent human beings think there 's something inherently wrong about sex ?THEODORE drops his eyes . ERNEST disgusted with him .I see ! Good people should drop their eyes even at the mention of the word .

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: Sex is a necessary evil , I admit , but ——

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: laughsEvil ! The God-given impulse which accounts for you sitting there , for me sitting here ? The splendid instinct which writes our poetry , builds our civilizations , founds our churches — the very heart and soul of life is evil . Really , Theodore , I do n't know much about religion , but that strikes me as blasphemy against the Creator .

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: Very scientific , my boy , very modern ; but the Church believed in marriage before Science was born .

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: As a compromise with evil ?

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: As a sacrament of religion — and so do you !

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: Good ! Then why practise and preach marriage as a sacrament of property ? “ Who giveth this woman to be married to this man — ” Women are still goods and chattels to be given or sold , are they ?

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: Oh , nonsense !

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: Then why keep on making them promise to “ serve and obey ” ? Why marry them with a ring — the link of the ancient chain ?He smiles .In the days of physical force it was made of iron — now of gold . But it 's still a chain , is n't it ?

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: Symbols , my dear fellow , not to be taken in a literal sense — time-honored and beautiful symbols .

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: But why insult a woman you respect — even symbolically ?

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: with a laughOh , you scientists !

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: joining in the laughWe try to find the truth — and you try to hide it , eh ? Well , there 's one thing we have in common , anyway — one faith I 'll never doubt again ; I believe in Heaven now . I always shall .

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: Do you mind telling me why , my boy ?

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: Not in the least . I 've been there .JOHN comes out to breakfast . He is scowling .Good morning ; could you spare me five minutes ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: ringing bellHave n't had breakfast yet .

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: After breakfast ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I 've an appointment with young Baker .

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: smilesI 'll wait my turn .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Going to be pretty busy to-day — you , too , I suppose , if you 're sailing to-morrow .

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: I can postpone sailing . This is more important .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I should hate to see anything interfere with your career .

div.stage: LUCY also arrives for breakfast . She “ always pours her husband 's coffee . ”

lg.l: I appreciate your interest , but I 'll look out for my “ career . ”
Could you tell me when your sister will be down ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: overriding LUCYMy sister is ill and wo n't be down at all ... until after you leave .

div.stage: LUCY pretends not to hear . THEODORE walks away .

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: aroused , but calmI do n't believe you quite understand . It is a matter of indifference to me whether we have a talk or not . Entirely out of courtesy to you that I suggest it .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Do n't inconvenience yourself on my account .

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: shrugs shoulders and turns to THEODOREWait , I think I 'll sit in church till train time .

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: smoothing it overCome along . I 'm going to preach about marriage !

div.stage: THEODORE starts off .

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: going , turns to LUCYThanks for your kindness . Will you ask the valet to pack my things , please ? I 'll call for them on the way to the station .To JOHN .Do you understand ? I have no favors to ask of you . You do n't own your sister — she owns herself .

div.stage: The scientist goes to church .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: with a loud laugh , turns to LUCYRather impertinent for a two-thousand-dollar man , I think .Resumes breakfast , picks up newspaper . LUCY says nothing , attending to his wants solicitously .Bah ! what does this highbrow know about the power men of my sort can use ... when we have to ?LUCY cringes dutifully in silence . JOHN , paper in one hand , brusquely passes cup to LUCY with other .Helen got her own way about college , about work , about living in her own apartment — but if she thinks she can put this across ! Humph ! These modern women must learn their place .LUCY , smiling timidly , returns cup . JOHN takes it without thanks , busied in newspapers . A look of resentment creeps over LUCY 'S pretty face , now that he can n't see her .Ah ! I 've got something up my sleeve for that young woman .LUCY says nothing , looks of contempt while he reads .Well , why do n't you say something ?

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: startledI thought you did n't like me to talk at breakfast , dear .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Think I like you to sit there like a mummy ?No reply .Have n't you anything to say ?Apparently not .You never have any more , nothing interesting .... Does it ever occur to you that I 'd like to be diverted ?... No !

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Yes .... Would you mind very much if ... if I left you , John ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Left me ? When — where — how long ?

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: gathering courageNow — any place — entirely .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: bursts out laughingWhat suddenly put this notion in your head ?

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: I 'm sorry — John , but I 've had it — oh , for years . I never dared ask you till now .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: still glancing over paperLike to leave me , would you ?... You have no grounds for divorce , my dear .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: But you will have — after I leave you .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: yawnsYou have no lover to leave with .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: daintilyBut could n't I just desert you — without anything horrid ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: readsNo money to desert with .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: springs up — at bayYou wo n't let me escape decently when I tell you I do n't want to stay ? When I tell you I can n't stand being under your roof any longer ? When I tell you I 'm sick of this life ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: gets up calmlyBut , you see , I can stand it . I want you to stay . I 'm not sick of it . You belong to me .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: shrinking away as he approachesDo n't touch me ! Every time you come near me I have to nerve myself to stand it .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: What 's got into you ? Do n't I give you everything money can buy ? My God , if I only gave you something to worry about ; if I ran after other women like old man Baker ——

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: If you only would !— Then you 'd let me alone . To me you are repulsive .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: taking hold of herLucy ! You are my wife .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: looking him straight in the eyeBut you do n't respect me , and I — I hate you — oh , how I hate you !

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: holds her fastI am your husband , your lawful husband .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: stops strugglingYes , this is lawful — but , oh , what laws you men have made for women !

div.stage: The JUDGE comes out , carrying a telegram .

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: Rather early in the day for conjugal embraces , if you should ask me .JOHN and LUCY separate .Makes me quite sentimental and homesick .

div.stage: JUDGE raises telegram and kisses it .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: calming herselfFrom Aunt Julia again ? Do you get telegrams every day from Reno ?

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: No , but she caught cold . Went to the theatre last night and caught a cold . So she wired me — naturally ; got the habit of telling me her troubles , can n't break it , even in Reno .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I thought she hated the theatre !

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: So she does , but I 'm fond of it ; she went for my sake . She 's got the habit of sacrificing herself for me . Just as hard to break good habits as bad .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: True women enjoy sacrificing themselves .

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: Yes , that 's what we tell them . Well , we ought to know . We make ‘ em do it .Brings out a fountain pen and sits abruptly .That 's what I 'll tell her . I can hear her laugh . You know her laugh .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: rings for a servantA telegraph blank ?

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: with a humorous expression he brings a whole pad of telegraph blanks out of another pocketCarry them with me nowadays .Begins to write .Wish I had n't sold my Western Union , John .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I do n't believe you want that divorce very much .

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: It does n't matter what I want — what she wants is the point . You must give the woman you marry tutti-frutti , divorces — everything .... Why , I 've got the habit myself , and God knows I do n't enjoy sacrifice — I 'm a man ! The superior sex !

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I do n't believe you appreciate that wife of yours .

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: between the words he 's writingDo n't I ? It is n't every wife that 'd travel away out to Reno — you know how she hates travelling — and go to a theatre — and catch a cold — and get a divorce — all for the sake of an uncongenial husband .Suddenly getting an idea , strikes table .I know what gave her a cold . She raised all the windows in her bedroom — for my sake !— I always kept them down for her sake . I 'll have to scold her .Bends to his writing again .Poor little thing ! She does n't know how to take care of herself without me . I doubt if she ever will .

div.stage: Looks over telegram . A SERVANT comes , takes telegram , and goes .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Uncle Everett , I want your advice .

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: John ! do you want a divorce ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: No , we are not that sort , are we , Lucy ?No answer .Are we , dear ?

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: after a pauseNo , we are not that sort !

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: We believe in the sanctity of the home , the holiness of marriage .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Yes , we believe in — “ the holiness of marriage ! ”

div.stage: Turns away , covering her face with her hands and shuddering .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Lucy , tell Helen and Jean to come here .LUCY goes .Well , young Baker spoke to me about Jean last night . I told him I 'd think it over and give him my decision this morning .

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: That 's right . Must n't seem too anxious , John . When the properly qualified male offers one of our dependent females a chance at woman 's only true career , of course it 's up to us to look disappointed .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: But I did n't bring up the little matter you spoke of .

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: About that chorus girl ?... Afraid of scaring him off ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Not at all , but — well , it 's all over and it 's all fixed . No scandal , no blackmail .

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: Hum ! By the way , got anything on Hamilton ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I do n't believe in saints myself .

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: I see .... Good thing , for Jean Rex is n't a saint . I suppose you 'd break off the match .

div.stage: REX , in riding clothes , comes out . JOHN salutes him warmly . The JUDGE is reading the paper .

sp.speaker: Well ?
sp.p: JOHN Well , of course , you realize that you 're asking a great deal of me , Rex , but —Offers hand to REX warmly .Be good to her , my boy , be good to her .

sp.speaker: REX
sp.p: shaking hands , forced warmthThanks awfully . See-what-I-mean ?To JUDGE .Congratulate me , Judge ; I 'm the happiest of men .

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: looking up from newspaperSo I see . Do n't let it worry you .

div.stage: JEAN , in riding costume , comes from the house .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: signalling JUDGE to leaveIf Helen asks for me , I 'm in the garden .

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: If any telegrams come for me , I 'm writing to my wife !

div.stage: JEAN and REX alone , they look at each other , not very loverlike .

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: impulsivelyYou were n't in love with me yesterday . You are n't now . You would get out of it if you honorably could . But you honorably can n't ! So you have spoken to John ; you are going to see it through , because you 're a good sport .... I admire you for that , Rex , too much to hold you to it . You are released .

sp.speaker: REX
sp.p: amazedWhy — why — you — you do n't suppose I want to be released ?

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: Well , I do !... Yesterday I let you propose to me when I cared for some one else . That 's not fair to you , to me , to him !

sp.speaker: REX
sp.p: in a sudden furyWho is he ? What do you mean by this ? Why did n't you tell me ?

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: I am telling you now . What have you ever told me about yourself ?

sp.speaker: REX
sp.p: blinkingYou had no right to play fast and loose with me .

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: I 'm making the only amends I can . You are free , I tell you .

sp.speaker: REX
sp.p: I do n't want to be free ! He can n't have you ! You are mine ! If you think you can make me stop loving you ——

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: interruptingLove , Rex ? Only jealousy . You 've never been in love with me — you 've always been in love with Helen . But you could n't get her , so you took me . Is n't that true , Rex ?

sp.speaker: REX
sp.p: after an uncomfortable pauseI 'll be honest with you , too . Yesterday I was n't really very serious . I felt like a brute afterward . You tried your best to prevent what happened and ran away from me . But now ——

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: Do n't you know why I ran away ? To make you follow . I made you catch me . I made you kiss me . Then you realized that we had been thrown together constantly — deliberately thrown together , if you care to know it — and , well , that 's how many marriages are made . But I sha n't marry on such terms . It 's indecent !

sp.speaker: REX
sp.p: another pauseI never thought a woman could be capable of such honesty !... Oh , what a bully sport you are ! You are n't like the rest that have been shoved at me . Why , I can respect you . You are the one for me .

div.stage: He tries to take her .

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: restraining him with dignityI am sorry , Rex , but I am not for you .

sp.speaker: REX
sp.p: Jean ! without you ... do n't you see — I 'll go straight to the devil !

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: That old , cowardly dodge ? Any man who has no more backbone than that — why , I would n't marry you if you were the last man in the world .

sp.speaker: REX
sp.p: frantic to possess what he cannot haveYou wo n't , eh ? We 'll see about that . I want you now as I never wanted anything in my life , and I 'll win you from him yet . You 'll see !

div.stage: HELEN now appears .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Oh , I beg your pardon . Lucy said John was out here .

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: I 'll call him .

div.stage: She runs down into the garden .

sp.speaker: REX
sp.p: I 'll call him .

div.stage: He runs after JEAN . HELEN helplessly watches them go , sighs , standing by the garden steps until JOHN ascends . He looks at HELEN a moment , wondering how to begin . She looks so capable and unafraid of him .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: If you had n't gone to college , you could have done what Jean is doing .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: with a shrug and a smileBut how proud you must be , John , to have a sister who is n't compelled to marry one man while in love with another . Now , are n't you glad I went to college ?

div.stage: She laughs good-naturedly at him .

lg.l: Humph ! If you think I 'd let a sister of mine marry one of old man
Baker 's two-thousand-dollar employees ——

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Why , John , did n't Ernest tell you ? Doctor Hawksbee has offered him a partnership . Just think of that !

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: What ! Going back into private practice ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: But it 's such a fashionable practice . Hawksbee 's made a million at it .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: But the institute needs Hamilton .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Ah , but we need the money !

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: disconcertedSo you are going to spoil a noble career , are you ? That 's selfish . I did n't think it of you . There are thousands of successful physicians , but there is only one Ernest Hamilton .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: laughsOh , do n't worry , John , he has promised me to keep his two-thousand-dollar job .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Ah , I 'm glad . You must let nothing interfere with his great humanitarian work . Think what it means to the lives of little children ! Think what it means to the future of the race ! Why , every one says his greatest usefulness has hardly begun !

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Oh , I know all that , I 've thought of all that .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Now , such men should be kept free from cares and anxiety . What was it you said yesterday ? “ He needs every cent of his salary for books , travel , all the advantages he simply must have for efficiency . ” To marry a poor man — most selfish thing a girl could do !

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Yes , John , that 's what I said yesterday .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: scoringBut that was before he asked you !HELEN smiles . He sneers .Rather pleased with yourself now , are n't you ? “ Just a woman after all ” — heroine of cheap magazine story ! Sacrifices career for love !... All very pretty and romantic , my dear — but how about the man you love ! Want to sacrifice his career , too ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: But I 'm not going to sacrifice what you are pleased to call my career .... Therefore he wo n't have to sacrifice his .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: What ! going to keep on working ? Will he let the woman he loves work !

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: demureWell , you see , he says I 'm “ too good ” to loaf .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Humph ! who 'll take care of your home when you 're at work ? Who 'll take care of your work when you 're at home . Look at it practically . To maintain such a home as he needs on such a salary as he has — why , it would take all your time , all your energy . To keep him in his class you 'll have to drop out of your own , become a household drudge , a servant .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: And if I am willing ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Then where 's your intellectual companionship ? How 'll you help his work ? Expense for him , disillusionment for both . If you 're the woman you pretend to be , you wo n't marry that man !

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: strongThe world needs his work , but he needs mine , and we both need each other .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: strongerAnd marriage would only handicap his work , ruin yours , and put you apart . You know that 's true . You 've seen it happen with others . You have told me so yourself !

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Then that settles it ! We must not , cannot , shall not marry . We have no right to marry . I agree with all you say — it would not join us together ; it would put us asunder .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: And you 'll give him up ? Good ! Good !

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Give him up ? Never ! The right to work , the right to love — those rights are inalienable . No , we 'll give up marriage but not each other .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: But — but — I do n't understand .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: straight in his eyesWe need each other — in our work and in our life — and we 're to have each other — until life is ended and our work is done . Now , do you understand ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: recoilingAre you in your right mind ? Think what you 're saying .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: I have thought all night , John . You have shown me how to say it .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: But , but — why , this is utterly unbelievable ! Why I 'm not even shocked . Do you notice ? I 'm not even shocked ? Because everything you have said , everything you have done — it all proves that you are a good woman .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: If I were a bad woman , I 'd inveigle him into marriage , John .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Inveigle ! Marriage ! Are you crazy ? ... Oh , this is all one of your highbrow jokes !

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: John , were n't you serious when you said marriage would destroy him ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: But this would destroy you !

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Well , even if that were so , which is more important to the world ? Which is more important to your “ great humanitarian work ” ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Ah , very clever ! A bluff to gain my consent to marrying him — a trick to get his salary raised .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: with forceJohn , nothing you can do , nothing you can say , will ever gain my consent to marrying him . I 've not told you half my reasons .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: My God ! my own sister ! And did you , for one moment , dream that I would consent to that !

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Not for one moment . I 'm not asking your consent . I 'm just telling you .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: after scrutinizing herRidiculous ! If you really meant to run away with this fellow , would you come and tell me , your own brother ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Do you suppose I 'd run away without telling , even my own brother ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: looks at her a moment ; she returns his gazeBah !— all pose and poppycock !He abruptly touches bell .I 'll soon put a stop to this nonsense .Muttering .Damnedest thing I ever heard of .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: John , I understand exactly what I 'm doing . You never will . But nothing you can do can stop me now .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: We 'll see about that .The BUTLER appears .Ask the others to step out here at once ; all except Miss Jean and Mr. Baker , I do n't want them . Is Doctor Hamilton about ?

sp.speaker: BUTLER
sp.p: No , sir , he went to church .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: All right .The BUTLER disappears .To church ! My God !

div.stage: HELEN pays no attention . She gazes straight out into the future , head high , eyes clear and wide open .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: First of all , when the others come out , I 'm going to ask them to look you in the face . Then you can make this statement to them , if you wish , and — look them in the face .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: with quiet scornIf I were being forced into such a marriage as poor little Jean 's , I would kill myself . But in the eyes of God , who made love , no matter how I may appear in the eyes of man , who made marriage , I know that I am doing right .

div.stage: LUCY comes out , followed by the JUDGE .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: not seeing them . He is loudSay that to Uncle Everett and Cousin Theodore ! Say that to my wife , stand up and say that to the world , if you dare .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: to JUDGEShe has told him !

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: wheeling aboutWhat ! did she tell you ? Why did n't you come to me at once ?

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: tremulousShe said she wanted to tell you herself . I did n't think she 'd dare !

div.stage: They all turn to look at HELEN . THEODORE comes back from church alone .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: It had to be announced , of course .

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: advancing , beamingAnnounced ? What is announced ?

div.stage: All turn to him in a panic .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: hurriedlyTheir engagement , Theodore !

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: overriding HELENYes , John has given his consent at last — example to society .

div.stage: Prods JOHN .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: also overrides HELENOf course ! One of the finest fellows in the world .

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: delightedAnd withal he has a deep religious nature . Congratulations . My dear , he 'll make an ideal husband .

div.stage: Takes both HELEN 'S hands , about to kiss her .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: can n't help smilingThank you , cousin , but I do n't want a husband .

div.stage: A sudden silence .

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: looks from one to the otherA lover 's quarrel ?— already !

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: enjoying itNo , Theodore , these lovers are in perfect accord . They both have conscientious scruples against marriage .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Conscientious !

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: So they are simply going to set up housekeeping without the mere formality of a wedding ceremony .

div.stage: THEODORE drops HELEN 'S hands .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: quietlyWe are going to do nothing of the sort .

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: Uncle Everett !

div.stage: Takes her hands again .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: We are not going to set up housekeeping at all . He will keep his present quarters and I mine .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: But they are going to belong to each other .

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: drops HELEN 'S hands — aghastI do n't believe it .

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: apart to THEODOREThe strike against marriage . It was bound to come .

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: to JUDGEBut Church and State —indicates self and JUDGEmust break this strike .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: John is a practical man . He will prove to you that such a home as we could afford would only be a stumbling-block to Ernest 's usefulness , a hollow sphere for mine . You can n't fill it with mere happiness , Lucy , not for long , not for long .

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: restrains THEODORE about to replyOh , let her get it all nicely talked out , then she 'll take a nap and wake up feeling better .Whispering .We 've driven her to this ourselves , but she really does n't mean a word of it . Come , dear child , tell us all about this nightmare .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: smiles at the JUDGEWhy , think what would happen to an eager intellect like Ernest Hamilton 's if he had to come back to a narrow-minded apartment or a dreary suburb every evening and eat morbid meals opposite a housewife regaling him with the social ambitions of the other commuters . Ugh ! It has ruined enough brilliant men already .JUDGE restrains THEODORE and others who want to interrupt .Now at the University Club he dines , at slight expense compared with keeping up a home , upon the best food in the city with some of the best scientists in the country .... Marriage would divorce him from all that , would transplant him from an atmosphere of ideas into an atmosphere of worries . We should be forced into the same deadly ruts as the rest of you , uncle . Do you want me to destroy a great career , Theodore ?

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: Do you want to be a blot upon that career ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: lightlyI 'd rather be a blot than a blight , and that 's what I 'd be if I became his bride . Ask John .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Do you want to be disgraced , despised , ostracized !

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: smiles at LUCYA choice of evils , dear ; of course , none of those costly well-kept wives on your visiting list will call upon me . But instead of one day at home , instead of making a tired husband work for me , I 'll have all my days free to work with him , like the old-fashioned woman you admire ! Instead of being an expense , I 'll be a help to him ; instead of being separated by marriage and divergent interests , we 'll be united by love and common peril .... Is n't that the orthodox way to gain character , Theodore ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Oh , this is all damned nonsense ! Look here , you 've either got to marry this fellow now or else go away and never see him again ; never , never !

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Just what I thought , John . I intended never to see him again . That was why I let you send me abroad . But I 'll never , never do it again .Smiling like an engaged girl .It was perfectly dreadful ! Ernest could n't get along without me at all , poor old thing . And I , why , I nearly died .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Then you 'll have to be married , that 's all .

sp.speaker: THE OTHERS
sp.p: Why , of course you 'll have to , that 's all .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: noddingOh , I know just how you feel about it . I thought so , too , at first , but I can n't marry Ernest Hamilton . I love him .

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: But if you love him truly — marriage , my dear , brings together those who love each other truly .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: But those who love each other truly do n't need anything to bring them together . The difficulty is to keep apart .

div.stage: A reminiscent shudder .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: That 's all romantic rot ! Every one feels that way at first .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: At first ! Then the practical object of marriage is not to bring together those who love each other , but to keep together those who do not ?To LUCY .What a dreadful thing marriage must be !

div.stage: JUDGE chokes down a chuckle .

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: Ah , so you wish to be free to separate . Now we have it .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: To separate ? What an idea ! On the contrary , we wish to be free to keep together ! In the old days when they had interests in common marriage used to make man and woman one , but now it puts them apart . Ca n't you see it all about you ? He goes down-town and works ; she stays up-town and plays . He belongs to the laboring class ; she belongs to the leisure class . At best , they seldom work at the same or similar trades . Legally it may be a union , but socially it 's a mesalliance — in the eyes of God it 's often worse .... No wonder that one in eleven ends in divorce . The only way to avoid spiritual separation is to shun legal union like a contagious disease . Modern marriage is divorce .She turns to go , defiantly .I 've found my work , I 've found my mate , and so has he ! What more can any human being ask ?

div.stage: The BUTLER appears .

sp.speaker: BUTLER
sp.p: to JOHNDoctor Hamilton is outside in a taxicab , sir .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Show him here at once !

sp.speaker: BUTLER
sp.p: He says he does not care to come in , sir , unless you are ready to talk to him now .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Well , of all the nerve ! You bet I 'm ready !

div.stage: Starts off . HELEN starts , too .

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: intercepting them calmlyWait a minute — wait a minute .To SERVANT .Ask Doctor Hamilton kindly to wait in the library .The BUTLER goes .Now , we 're all a bit overwrought .Soothes HELEN , pats her hand , puts arm about her , gradually leads her back .I still believe in you , Helen , I still believe in him .To all .It 's simply that he 's so deeply absorbed in his great work for mankind that he does n't realize what he is asking Helen to do .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: quietlySo I told him ... when he asked me to marry him .

sp.speaker: ALL
sp.p: What ! He asked you to marry him ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Of course ! Implored me to marry him .She adds , smiling .So absorbed — not in mankind , but in me — that he “ did n't realize what he was asking me to do . ”

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: utterly amazedAnd you refused him ! The man who loves you honorably ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: demurelyOf course ! You do n't suppose I 'd take advantage of the poor fellow 's weakness . Women often do , I admit — even when not in love , sometimes .... Not because they 're depraved but dependent .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: to allAnd then he proposed this wicked substitute ! Poisoned her innocent mind — the bounder !

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: But he did nothing of the sort .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Oh , your own idea , was it ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Of course !

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: to allAnd he is willing to take advantage of the poor child 's ignorance — the cad !To THEODORE .“ Deep religious nature , ” eh ?

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: I can n't believe it of him .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: He knows nothing about it yet . I have n't even seen him since I made my decision .

div.stage: All exchange bewildered glances .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: apart to JUDGEWe 've got to get him off to Paris . It 's our only hope .

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: apart to JOHNYou can n't stop her following . She 's on the edge of the precipice — do you want to shove her over ? You are dealing with big people here and a big passion .

div.stage: The BUTLER returns .

sp.speaker: BUTLER
sp.p: Doctor Hamilton asks to see Miss Helen while waiting .

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: calmly to BUTLERTell Doctor Hamilton that Miss Helen will see him here .

div.stage: The BUTLER leaves .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Are you crazy ! We 've got to keep ‘ em apart — our one chance to save her .

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: No , bring them together . That is our one chance . Come , we 'll go down into the garden and they 'll have a nice little talk . Nothing like talk , John , honest talk , to clear these marriage problems .

div.stage: Going .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: And let them elope ? In that taxicab ?— not on your life !

div.stage: Runs to and fro .

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: Come , John , girls never notify the family in advance when they plan elopements . It 's not done .

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: goingUncle Everett is right . Ernest will bring her to her senses . He has a deep religious nature .

div.stage: JUDGE leads JOHN away to the garden .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: lingering — to HELENIf you offer yourself on such terms to the man who loves you honorably , he 'll never look at you again .

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: leading LUCY off to gardenDo n't worry ! She wo n't .

div.stage: ERNEST rushes out to HELEN .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Ernest !

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: At last !He takes her in his arms ; she clings to him and gazes into his eyes ; a long embrace .Tell me that you 're all right again .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: smiling with love and trustExcept that you deserted me , dear , just when I needed you most . Ernest , Ernest ! never leave me again .

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: Deserted you ? Why , your brother said you were ill .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Ah , I see ... he was mistaken .

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: jubilant and boyishBut never mind now , I 've got you at last , and I 'll never , never let you go . You 've got to sail with me to-morrow . Together ! Oh , think ! Together .

div.stage: Another embrace .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Are you sure you love me ?

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: laughs from sheer joy of her nearnessAm I sure ? Ten million times more to-day than yesterday .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Even so ... it is not , and can never be , as I love you .

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: with her hands in his , gaylyThen you can apologize .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Apologize ?

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: For saying , years and years ago — in other words , last night — that you did n't think you 'd marry me after all .She starts .Why , what 's the matter ? You 're trembling like a leaf . You are ill !

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: No ; oh , no .

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: tenderlyStill a few lingering doubts ? I had hoped a good night 's rest would put those little prejudices to sleep forever .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Sleep ?

div.stage: She shakes her head , gazing at him soberly .

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: So you could not sleep ? Neither could I ; I was too happy to sleep . I was afraid I 'd miss some wondrous throbbing thought of your loveliness .Takes her passive hand , puts a kiss in it , and closes it reverently while she looks into his eyes without moving .Do you know , I 'm disappointed in love . I always thought it meant soft sighs and pretty speeches . It means an agony of longing , delicious agony , but , oh , terrific .She says nothing .Dear , dear girl , it may be easy for you , but I can n't stand much more of this .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Nor I .

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: You must come to Paris with me or I 'll stay home . All through the night I had waking visions of our being parted . Just when we had found each other at last . Some terrible impersonal monster stepped in between us and said : “ No . Now that you have had your glimpse of heaven — away ! Ye twain shall not enter here .... ” Silly , was n't it ? But I could n't get the horror of it out of my head .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: noddingDo you know why , Ernest ? Because it was in mine . It came from my thought to yours . You and I are attuned like wireless instruments . Even in the old blind days , there in the laboratory I used to read your mind . Shall I tell you the name of the monster that would put us asunder ?... Its name is Marriage .

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: But I need you . You know that . And you need me . It 's too late . We are helpless now — in the clutch of forces more potent than our little selves — forces that brought us into the world — forces that have made the world . Whether you will or no , this beautiful binding power is sweeping you and me together . And you must yield .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: reaching for his handAh , my dear , could anything make it more beautiful , more binding than it is now ?

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: It is perfect . The one divine thing we share with God . The Church is right in that respect . I used to look upon marriage as a mere contract . It 's a religious sacrament .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Does the wedding ceremony make it sacred ?

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: That mediaeval incantation ! No , love , which is given by God , not the artificial form made by man .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: I knew it ! I knew you 'd see it — the mistake of all the ages . They 've tried to make love fit marriage . It can n't be done . Marriage must be changed to fit love .Impulsively .Yes , I 'll go to Paris with you .

p.stage: about to take her in his arms

sp.speaker: You darling !
sp.p: HELENsteps backBut not as your wife .

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: stops — perplexedYou mean ... without marriage ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: I mean without marriage .

div.stage: They look into each other 's eyes .

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: A moment ago I thought I loved you as much as man could love woman . I was mistaken in you — I was mistaken in myself . For now I love you as man never loved before . You superb , you wonderful woman !

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: holds out her hand to be shaken , not caressedThen you agree ?

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: kneels , kisses her hand , and arisesOf course not ! You blessed girl , do n't you suppose I understand ? It 's all for my sake . Therefore for your sake — no .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Then for my sake — for the sake of everything our love stands for !

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: laughing fondlyDo you think I 'd let you do anything for anybody 's sake you 're sure , later , to regret ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Then do n't ask me to marry you , Ernest . We 'd both regret that later . It would destroy the two things that have brought us together , love and work .

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: Nonsense . Nothing could do that .... And besides , think of our poor horrified families ! Think of the world 's view !

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Are n't we sacrificing enough for the world — money , comforts , even children ? Must we also sacrifice each other to the world ? Must we be hypocrites because others are ? Must we , too , be cowards and take on the protective coloring of our species ?

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: Our ideas may be higher than society 's , but society rewards and punishes its members according to its own ideas , not ours .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Do you want society 's rewards ? Do you fear society 's punishment ?

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: jubilantly enfolding herWith you in my arms , I want nothing from heaven , I fear nothing from hell ; but , my dearshrugs and comes down to earth with a smile and releases her, consider the price , consider the price .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Are n't you willing to pay the price ?

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: I ? Yes ! But it 's the woman , always the woman , who pays .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: I am willing to pay .

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: I am not willing to let you .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: You 'll have to be , dear . I shall go with you on my terms or not at all .

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: with decisionYou will come with me as my wife or stay at home .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: gaspingNow ? After all I 've said , all I 've done ? Ernest : I 've told the family ! I relied upon you . I took for granted — Ernest , you would n't — you could n't leave me behind now .

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: Thanks to you and what you 've made of me , I must and will .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Ernest !

div.stage: Opens her arms to him to take her .

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: about to enfold her — resistsNo ! If you love me enough for thatpoints to her pleading hands— I love you enough for this .He turns to go .Come when you 're ready to marry me .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: shrill , excited , angeredDo you think this has been easy for me ? Do you think I 'll offer myself again on any terms ? Never !

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: You must marry me — and you will .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: You do n't know me . Good-by !

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: Very well !

div.stage: ERNEST , afraid to stay , goes at once . She waits motionless until she hears the automobile carrying him away . She immediately turns from stone to tears , with a low wail . In utter despair , hands outstretched she sinks down upon a bench and buries her face in her hands .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Oh , Ernest !... How could you ?

div.stage: LUCY , THEODORE , JUDGE and JOHN all hurry back , all excited .

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: Did you see his horrified look ?

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Fairly running away — revolted . Ah !

div.stage: Points at HELEN . HELEN arises , defiant , confident , calm .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: to HELENWhat did I tell you !

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: You have thrown away the love of an honorable man .

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: Trampled upon the finest feelings of a deep nature .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Let this be a lesson to you . You 've lost your chance to marry , your chance to work , and now , by heavens ! you will cut out “ independence ” and stay at home , where women belong , and live down this disgrace ... if you can .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: With one excuse or another — he 'll stay away . He 'll never come back .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: clear and confident as if clairvoyantHe will ! He is coming now .... He is crossing the hall .... He is passing through the library .... He 's here !

div.stage: But she does n't turn . ERNEST reappears at the door and takes in the situation at a glance .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: still turned toward HELENHe 'll never look at you again , and I do n't blame him ! I 'm a man ; I know . We do n't respect women who sell out so cheap .

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: You lie !All turn , astounded . HELEN runs toward ERNEST with a cry of joy . JOHN starts to block her . To JOHN .Stop ! You 're not fit to touch her . No man is .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: with a sarcastic laughHumph ! I suppose that 's why you ran away .

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: Yes . To protect her from myself .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Then why come back ?

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: To protect her from you ! You cowards , you hypocrites !He rushes down to HELEN , puts his strong arm about shoulder and whispers rapidly .Just as I started , something stopped me . In a flash I saw ... all this .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: clasping his arm with both handsI made you come ! I made you see !

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: advances menacinglyBy what right are you here in my home ? By what right do you take my sister in your arms ?

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: By a right more ancient than man-made law ! I have come to the cry of my mate . I 'm here to fight for the woman I love !Arm about HELEN , defies the world . To all .My trip to Paris is postponed . One week from to-day gather all your family here , and in your home we 'll make our declaration to the world .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: In my home ! Ha ! Not if I know it .

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: restraining JOHNPlay for time , John — he 'll bring her around .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: to ERNESTDo you mean to marry her or not ? Speak my language !

div.stage: ERNEST releases HELEN and steps across to JOHN .

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: She decides that — not you .

div.stage: All turn to HELEN .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Never !

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: shaking off JUDGE . To HELEN .You 'll go with this damned fanatic only over my dead body .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: highAnd that will only cry aloud the thing you wish to hide from the world you fear .

div.stage: Just now JEAN is seen slowly returning from the garden without REX . Her pretty head is bent and , busy with her own sad thoughts , she is startled by the following :

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: There are laws to prevent marriage in some cases but none to enforce marriage on women — unless they will it .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: beside himself with rageEnforce ! Do you think I 'll ever allow a sister of mine to marry a libertine ?

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: thinks they are discussing her , and is outragedBut I 'm not going to marry him ! My engagement is broken .

div.stage: General consternation . Sobbing , JEAN runs into house .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: My God , what next ? Lucy , do n't let Rex get away ! You know what he 'll do — and when he sobers up , it may be too late .To ERNEST .As for you , you snake , you get right out of here .

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: in the sudden silenceNow you 've done it , John .

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: Oh , very well , this is your property .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: But I am not ! I go , too !

div.stage: She runs to ERNEST .

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: Do n't commit this sin !

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Let her go ! She 's no sister of mine .

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: the only calm oneIf she leaves this house now , it 's all up .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: A woman who will give herself to a man without marriage is no sister of mine .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: about to go , turns , leaning on ERNEST . To allGive !... But if I sold myself , as you are forcing poor little Jean to do , to a libertine she does not love , who does not love her — that is not sin ! That is respectability ! To urge and aid her to entrap a man into marriage by playing the shameless tricks of the only trade men want women to learn — that is holy matrimony . But to give yourself of your own free will to the man you love and trust and can help , the man who loves and needs and has won the right to have you — oh , if this is sin , then let me live and die a sinner !

div.stage: She turns to ERNEST , gives him a look of complete love and trust , then bursts into tears upon his shoulder , his arms enfolding her protectingly .

div.head: ACT III

stage.stage: It is well along in the afternoon of the same busy day of rest . Most unaccountably — until the JUDGE accounts for it later — the terrace has been decked out with festoons and flowers since the excitement of the morning . Japanese lanterns have been hung , though it is not yet time to light them and though it is Sunday in a pious household .
Most incongruously and lugubriously , LUCY is pacing to and fro in silent concern .

sp.speaker: THEODORE now comes out of the house , also looking harassed . Lucy
sp.p: turns to him inquiringly . He shakes his head sadly .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: No word from Uncle Everett ?

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: No word . He must have reached town long ago , unless he had tire trouble .... It 's a bad sign , Lucy , a bad sign . He would surely telephone us .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Oh , if he only had n't missed their train !

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: hopelesslyUncle Everett is the only one who could have brought them to their senses .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: It may not be too late . He took our fastest car , our best chauffeur .

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: Detectives are to watch all the steamers to-morrow . John telephoned at once .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: But to-morrow will be too late ! And , oh ! when it all comes out in the newspapers ! The ghastly head-lines — “ well-known scientist , beautiful daughter of a prominent family ! ” Oh ! What will people say ?

div.stage: JOHN , hurried and worried , rushes out shouting for LUCY .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Any news ? Any news ?THEODORE and LUCY give him gestures of despair .Then it 's too late .He , too , paces to and fro in fury . Then bracing up .Well , I found Rex , over at the Golf Club . Terribly cut up . But listen ; not a drink , not one !... Where 's Jean ? Got to see her at once .

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: Locked herself up in her room , John , crying her little heart out !

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Rex is a changed man , I tell you . We 've got to patch it up , and we 've got to do it quick !

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: But , John ! When the Bakers hear about Helen ... Rex marry into our family ? Never ! We 're disgraced , John , disgraced !

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: impatientlyBut they 're not going to hear about Helen . No one knows , and no one will . Helen has simply returned to Paris to complete her scientific research . My press-agent — he 's attending to all that .

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: But questions , gossip , rumor — it 's bound to come out in time !

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: In time ; but meanwhile , if Jean marries Rex , the Bakers will have to stand for it . What 's more , they 'll make other people stand for it . Backed by the Bakers , no one will dare turn us down .... Our position in the world , my business relations with the old man — everything hangs on little Jean now . Tell her I 've simply got to see her .LUCY hesitates .Hurry ! Rex is coming over later .He catches sight of the table , festoons , etc .Heavens ! What 's all this tomfoolery ?

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: goingUncle Everett 's orders — he would n't stop to explain . He left word to summon the whole family for dinner .

div.stage: LUCY goes .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: shrillyThe whole family !... To-day of all days !

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: John ! You must not , shall not , force Jean to marry this man .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: unappreciatedHave n't I done everything for my sisters ? Ca n't they even marry for me ?

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: The man she loves or none at all .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: That cub at the law school ? No money to keep a wife , no prospects of any . His father 's a college professor .

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: shaking head sadly“ No love without marriage , no marriage without — money ! ” Ernest Hamilton 's words this morning , when we walked to church .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: watching house expectantlySurvival of the fittest , Theodore , survival of the fittest .

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: The fittest for what ?— for making money ! the only kind of fitness encouraged to survive , to reproduce its species .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: If the ability to make money is not the test of fitness , what is ?

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: Then you are more fit than a hundred Hamiltons , are you ? And Rex ? How fit is he ? Rex never made a cent in his life .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: He 's got it , all the same .... See here ! Have n't I enough to worry me without your butting in ? Jean 's got to marry somebody , sometime , has n't she ?

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: But not Rex , not if I can prevent it .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: But you can n't — you have nothing to do with it ... except to perform the ceremony and get a big , fat fee for it .

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: I — marry Jean and Rex ? Never !

div.stage: JEAN comes out . She is frightened and turns timidly to THEODORE for protection .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Jean , do n't detain Theodore . He has an important business letter to write .THEODORE turns to JOHN indignantly .Your wife 's sanatorium bills — better settle up before they dun you again .

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: With your money ?

div.stage: Takes JOHN 'S check out of pocket , about to tear it .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: catching THEODORE 'S handFor Mary 's sake , for the children 's — do n't give way to selfish pride .... Want to kill your wife ? Then take her out of the sanatorium . Want to ruin your children ? Then take them out of school !... Cash your check , I tell you , and pay your debts !

div.stage: THEODORE glances at JEAN , at check . A struggle . At bay , he finally pockets check and dejectedly goes into the house .

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: with a wet handkerchief in handWell ? If I refuse to marry Rex ?... Cut off my allowance or merely bully me to death ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: kindlyOh , come ! You 've filled your romantic little head full of novels . I never force anybody to do anything .Suddenly breaks out .My heavens ! what 's the matter with all of you ? I only want to give you and Lucy and Helen and Theodore and the whole family the best of everything in life ! And what do I get for it ? I 'm a brutal husband , a bullying brother , and a malefactor of wealth . Lord ! I guess I have some rights , even if I have got money !

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: Rex has money , too . Should that give him the right to women ? I , too , have some rights — even though I am a woman .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Any woman who can n't care enough for a Baker to marry him — Rex is the sort who would do everything in the world for the woman he loves , everything . All the Bakers are like that .

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: But what would he do for the woman he no longer loves ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: He was n't fool enough to tell you about that ?

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: About what ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: haltingNothing — I thought — I tell you , Rex has reformed .

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: You thought I meant his “ past . ” I meant his future ... and my own .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Well , if you expect to find a saint , you 'll never get married at all .

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: And if I never married at all ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Then what will you do ?

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: with a wail of despairThat 's it — then what should I do — what could I do ? Oh , it 's so unfair , so unfair to train girls only for this ! What chance , what choice have I ? To live on the bounty of a disapproving brother or a man I do not love ! Oh , how I envy Helen ! If I only had a chance , a decent chance !

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Any sensible girl would envy your chance . You 'll never have another like it . You 'll never have another at all ! Grab it , I tell you , grab it .REX comes quietly , a determined look on his face , JOHN sees him .Now , think , before too late , think hard . Think what it means to be an old maid .

div.stage: And leaves them abruptly .
JEAN stands alone , looking very pretty in girlish distress . REX gazes at her a moment and then with sudden passion he silently rushes over , seizes her in his arms , kisses her furiously .

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: indignant , struggles , frees herself , and rubs her cheekUgh ! How could you !

sp.speaker: REX
sp.p: Because I love you !

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: Love ! It is n't even respect now .

sp.speaker: REX
sp.p: Has that fellow ever kissed you ?

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: I have begged you never to refer to him again .

sp.speaker: REX
sp.p: He has ! He has held you in his arms . He has kissed your lips , your cheeks , your eyes !

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: How many women have you held in your arms ? Have I ever tried to find out ?

sp.speaker: REX
sp.p: Ah ! You do n't deny it , you can n't .

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: I can ! He respects me . I do n't deserve it , but he does .

sp.speaker: REX
sp.p: Thank heavens ! Oh , you do n't know how this has tormented me , little Jean . The thought of any other man 's coming near you — why , I could n't have felt the same toward you again , I just could n't .

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: bites her lips — then deliberatelyWell , then ... other men have come near me ... other men have kissed me , Rex .

sp.speaker: REX
sp.p: getting wild againWhat ! When ? Where ?

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: laughing cynicallyOh , in conservatories in town , John 's camp in the North Woods , motor rides in the country — once or twice out here on this very terrace , when I 've felt sentimental in the moonlight .

sp.speaker: REX
sp.p: recoilingOh ! Jean ! I never supposed you were that sort !

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: with distasteOh , I do n't make a habit of it ! I 'm not that sort . But ... well , this is n't all I could tell you about myself , Rex .

sp.speaker: REX
sp.p: Do n't !... Oh , what do you mean — quick .

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: Oh , I 've merely been handled , not hurt . Slightly shop-worn but as good as new .

sp.speaker: REX
sp.p: after a pause , quietlyJean , what makes you say such horribly honest things to me ?

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: Yesterday I did you a great unkindness , Rex . I deserve to suffer for it .... You do n't suppose I enjoy talking this way about myself ?

sp.speaker: REX
sp.p: I never heard a girl — a nice girl — talk like this before .

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: Naturally not . Usually “ nice ” girls hide it . It 's an instinct in women — to keep up their value .... Often I 've had thoughts and feelings which “ nice ” girls of your artificial ideal are supposed never to have at all . Perfectly natural , too , especially girls of my sort . We have so little to occupy our minds , except men ! To have a useful , absorbing occupation — it rubs off the bloom , lowers our price in the market , you see .

sp.speaker: REX
sp.p: Oh , stop !... If you 're not going to marry me , say so , but ——

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: But I am !... I am not going to be a dependent old maid .REX , bewildered , only gazes at her .But , first , I want you to know exactly what you 're getting for your money . That seems only businesslike .

sp.speaker: REX
sp.p: recoilsWould you only marry me for that ?

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: I told you I loved another man . Do you want me ?

sp.speaker: REX
sp.p: with jealousy returningDo I want you ! He sha n't have you .

div.stage: He comes close .

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: Then take me .

sp.speaker: REX
sp.p: seizes her passionatelyI 'll make you love me !Kisses her triumphantly .I 'll bring a different light into those cold eyes of yours . Wait until you 're married ! Wait until you 're awakened . I 'll make you forget that man , all other men . You are to be mine — all mine , all mine !During this embrace JEAN is quite passive , holds up her cheek to be kissed , and when he seeks her lips she shuts her eyes and gives him her lips . He suddenly stops , chilled ; holding her at arms length .But I do n't care to marry an iceberg . Ca n't you love me a little ? Have n't you any sentiment in your cynical little soul ... you irresistible darling !

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: In my soul ? Yes ! It 's only my body I 'm selling , you know .

div.stage: Then deliberately — clearly without passion — throws her arms about his neck , clinging close and kissing him repeatedly until REX responds .

sp.speaker: REX
sp.p: Look out , here comes the parson .

div.stage: THEODORE comes out of the house .

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: Oh , Theodore ! Rex and I have come to an understanding .... Will you solemnize our blessed union ?

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: Not unless you truly love each other . Marriage is sacred .

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: rapidlyA large church wedding — that will make it sacred . A full choral service — many expensive flowers — all the smartest people invited — that always makes the union of two souls sacred .

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: Those who truly love — their friends should witness the solemn rite , but ——

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: interrupts . To REXAnd my wedding gown will be white satin with a point-lace veil caught up with orange-blossoms and a diamond tiara — “ the gift of the groom ” — that ought to make it solemn .

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: The white veil is the symbol of purity , Jean .

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: rattling on wildlyOf purity , Rex , do you hear ? Whenever you see a bride in the white symbol of purity she is pure — that proves it . That makes it all so beautiful ! so sacred ! so holy ! holy ! holy !

div.stage: Hysterically turns and runs into the house as JOHN comes out .

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: followingJean , you must not , you shall not —JOHN blocks THEODORE . REX runs in after JEAN . To JOHN .John , I warn you ! I 'll prevent this marriage . I 'll tell every clergyman in the diocese . I 'll inform the bishop himself . This marriage would be a sacrilege .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: You dare threaten me — after all I 've done for you !

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: Your five thousand was a loan — not a bribe — every cent of it will be returned .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: You can n't return it . I would n't let you if you could . Come , it 's all in the family .THEODORE shakes his head .You know that beautiful Gothic chapel old man Baker is building on his estate ? He likes you . I 'll tell him you 're just the man he 's looking for — safe and sane — no socialistic tendencies .

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: Do n't trouble yourself — he offered me the place this morning .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: You did n't refuse it !

lg.l: I did — this morning . But since my last talk with you I 've reconsidered ,
I 've telephoned my acceptance .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: genuinely gladBully ! Great ! Why , now you 're fixed for life . “ Only one kind of fitness encouraged , ” eh ?... Right always triumphs in the end . Never lose your faith again , Theodore .

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: Right ? That whited sepulchre ! his mill hands dying like flies , his private life a public scandal !

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: with a cynical grinThen why accept his tainted money ?

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: from his soulTo keep my wife alive . To keep my children out of the streets . To keep myself out of deeper debt to you . That 's why I accept it — that 's why many a man sells his soul to the devil .... If I had only myself to consider — why , to me a little thing like death would be a blessed luxury . But I , why , John , I cannot afford — even to die . I must compromise and live — live for those dependent on me .... Your five thousand will be returned with interest , but your little sister will not be married to a man she does not want .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: But Rex wants her and money talks in this world , louder than the Church . Refuse to marry Baker 's son and how long will you keep Baker 's chapel ?... Think it over , Theodore , think it over .

div.stage: Suddenly the JUDGE in motor garments covered with dust comes out panting , followed by LUCY calling .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Uncle Everett ! Uncle Everett !

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: John ! Oh , John !

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Where is she !

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: You were too late !

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: Wait ! Give me time to get my breath .

div.stage: Fans himself with his cap and mops brow .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: My detective — did n't he meet their train ?

div.stage: JUDGE nods yes .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: But they saw him first ?

div.stage: JUDGE shakes head no .

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: Did n't he follow them ?

div.stage: JUDGE nods yes .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Where 'd they go ? Where are they ? Speak , man , speak !

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: raises cap and handkerchiefNow , just give me a chance and I 'll tell the whole story .... The detective was waiting at the station . He saw them step out of the train . He followed them to the cab-stand . He watched them get into a taxi — jumped into another himself — and away they went , pursued by the detective and blissfully ignorant of his existence .... Even now they do n't know they were being watched — or else ... well , they might have taken another course .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Quick ! Tell us the worst .

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: hesitatesWell ... they drove straight to Helen 's apartment .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: And you were too late . I thought so .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: But my detective ?

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: He followed and reported to me when I reached town .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Reported what ? Tell us all .

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: First he saw Ernest help Helen out of the taxi — very tenderly , like this . Little they realized then how every detail was to be reported to you now !

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Go on ! Go on !

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: Then the detective saw Ernest deliberately ——

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Yes , go on .

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: Deliberately lift his hat like this , say “ good afternoon ” just like that , and drive on to his own apartment a mile away .

div.stage: There is a sudden silence ; the others waiting the JUDGE now sits down .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Oh , is that all ?

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: Why , it 's exactly as if they were engaged !

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: No , Theodore , not exactly as if engaged .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: You 're keeping something back from us ! Speak !

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: gets up from chairMust I tell you ? It 's rather delicate .... Well , he did n't even step into the vestibule to kiss her good-by .

div.stage: All look at each other .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: But where are they now ? Quick !

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: They met later ! I knew it .

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: Yes , it 's true . They are alone together at this very moment .

sp.speaker: ALL
sp.p: Where ! Where ?

lg.l: JOHN
What ! What are they doing here ?

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: resumes fanningDiscussing the marriage problem .General rejoicing and relief .Sssh ! Not so loud , you might interrupt them .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: nodding knowinglyCold feet ! Knew he 'd lose his job .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: The disgrace . She could n't face it .

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: No , conscience . A deep religious nature .

div.stage: They all think it over a moment , each sure of his own diagnosis .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: turning to JUDGE with amusementSo ! Decided the soul-mate theory would n't work in practice , eh ?

sp.speaker: THEODORE and LUCY
sp.p: And they agree to marry ?

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: stops fanningMarry ? My , no ! Nothing like that . They think less of marriage than ever now ! Helen is using woman 's sweet indirect influence on Ernest in there at this moment !

div.stage: All start toward the house impulsively , but on second thoughts they all stop .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Then how on earth did you get them back !

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: lighting cigarOh , perfectly simple , I promised Helen you 'd apologize to Ernest ; promised Ernest you 'd apologize to Helen .To LUCY .Promised both you 'd arrange a nice little family party for ‘ em . They bear no grudge . They 're too happy .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: horrified . Indicates tableThe family party — for them ? Horrors !

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: tossing away matchYes , here in your happy home .The others turn on the JUDGE indignantly .Well , do n't jump on me . I tell you they positively decline to elope until after they tell the whole damn family . Considerate of them , I say . You do n't deserve it , if you ask me .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: incredulousTell the whole ... see here , are they crazy ? Are you crazy ? Do you think I 'm crazy ?

div.stage: Impetuously turns toward the house , a man of action .

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: stopping JOHNWait !... You 've already done your best to destroy your sister — but you 've utterly failed . They have done nothing wrong — as yet . Why , they are the finest , truest , noblest pair of lovers I ever met ! Now , are n't they , Theodore ?

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: I can n't say that I call Helen 's ideas of marriage “ noble , ” exactly !

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: grandiloquentShe is willing to sacrifice even marriage for his career . Is n't that noble ? And he ! willing to sacrifice even his career for marriage . Both noble , if you ask me .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: loudNoble tommy-rot !— a pair of pig-headed , highbrow fools ! They do n't have to sacrifice anything for anybody . Ca n't they work together just as well married as unmarried ?

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: slylyThat 's what I said to her , but you had already convinced her that it was impractical . Work and marriage — “ combine the two , and you 'll fail at both ” — your own warning , John .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: angryB'r ' r — you think you 're very funny , do n't you ! But that 's my sister in there , planning to be that fellow 's mistress — right here in my own house ! Anything funny about that !

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: stepping asideAll right , go put a stop to it then !JOHN starts toward house .It 's your own house — turn her out again .JOHN stops short .What are you going to do about it , John ?JOHN has no answer .Drive little Jean into marriage with a man she does not love — she is an old-fashioned girl . But your other sister — you can n't make her marry even the man she does love , unless she sees fit . She is the New Woman ! Society can no longer force females into wedlock — so it is forcing them out ... by the thousands ! Approve of it ? Of course not . But what good will our disapproval do ? They will only laugh at you . The strike is on . Few of the strikers will let you see it . Few of the strikers have Helen 's courage . But , believe it or not , the strike will spread . It cannot be crushed by law or force . Unless society wakes up and reforms its rules and regulations of marriage , marriage is doomed .... What are you going to do about it ?Silence .I thought so — nothing . Call them bad women and let it go at that . Blame it all on human nature , made by God , and leave untouched our human institutions , made by man . You poor little pessimists ! human nature to-day is better than it ever was , but our most important institution is worse — the most sacred relationship in life has become a jest in the market-place .... You funny little cowards , you 're afraid of life , afraid of love , afraid of truth . You worship lies , and call it God !

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: interruptsAll right , all right — but we can n't change marriage overnight just to suit Helen . What are you going to do about it ?

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: There 's just one thing to do . Will you back me up in everything I say ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: acknowledging his own defeatAnything — everything .

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: Then tell Helen she does n't have to marry , that , with the best intentions , the Church has made a muddle of monogamy .

div.stage: Illustration : From a photograph by White Studio .

sp.speaker: JUDGE : You poor little pessimists ! Human nature to-day is better
sp.p: than it ever was , but our most important institution is worse — the most sacred relationship in life has become a jest in the market-place . ]

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: Uncle Everett , I protest .

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: That we all admire their consecrated courage and advise their trying this conscientious experiment .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Not if I have anything to say about it !

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: But you have n't . Do please get that through your head .... Theodore , they 've talked enough , ask them to step out here and receive John 's blessing .Impatiently .Go on — I 'll fix John .THEODORE goes .To JOHN , who is about to burst forth .Oh , see here , did you ever pull a dog into the house against his will ?... Let him alone and he 'll follow you in , wag his tail , and lick your hand .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: You mean , they 'll come in , be respectable ?

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: Admit that marriage has numerous drawbacks — and they 'll see its advantages . Deny it — and they 'll see nothing but each other . Marriage is in a bad way , but it 's the less of two evils . Marriage must adjust itself to the New Woman — but the New Woman must meanwhile adjust herself to marriage .Briskly to LUCY .Now , then , did you send out that hurry call for the family this evening ?

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Yes , they 're on their way here now , but Uncle Everett , Doctor Hamilton said , next week .

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: Yes , I know — it 'll be a little surprise party for Helen .... Did you order some music ?

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Yes , the musicians are to be stationed in the library .

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: Excellent , excellent .Indicates tables and festoons .All that junk will help , too . A good Sunday supper this evening , Lucy ; your best champagne , John — gay spirits , family affection , warm approval , toasts to the future . Why , all we 'll have to do is —Breaks off .Here they come . Now follow my lead . They 've done a lot of thinking since you saw them last , but — make one misstep and it 's all off .

sp.speaker: LUCY
sp.p: Be nice to her , John . It was just a girlish impulse .

div.stage: JOHN opens arms to receive HELEN .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: My sister ! All is forgiven .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: stops short , her lip curlsYou forgive me ?

div.stage: Before JOHN can reply , THEODORE and ERNEST follow , talking .

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: But I tell you he had a perfect right to put me off his property . The thing I can n't overlook —Sees JOHN and LUCY . Points finger at them accusingly .Theodore has told me what you thought .... Please do n't judge us by yourselves again — you licentious-minded married people !

div.stage: He shrugs his shoulders with fastidious disgust and turns his back upon them .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: gaspingWell , I 'll be damned .

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: whispersStand for it — he 's right .

sp.speaker: THEODORE
sp.p: But Ernest ... I 'm bound to say when two people run away together ——

sp.speaker: ERNEST
sp.p: Ah , Theodore ! you , too ? Are all married people alike ? Did we want to “ run away ” as you call it ? Did we not ask for a week to think it over ? Did we not stipulate that in any case we must frankly face the family first ? But this person — what did he do ? he ordered us off his property , like trespassers ! What could we do ? Sit down in the road and wait a week ? Bah ! we went home — you suspicious married people , you hypocritical , unspeakable married people !JUDGE has difficulty in restraining JOHN .Why , I believe our good friend the Judge here is the only decent-minded , properly married person on your property .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: bursting outDecent-minded — why , he 's div ——

div.stage: LUCY stops him .

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: steps inDev-oted to his wife . Lucy is jealous of what I 'm doing for my wife .Controls laughter .Now come , we must all just let bygones be bygones . We know your intentions are honorable , your courage admirable ; and for whatever was amiss in word , deed , or thought , we all humbly apologize — do n't we , John ?JOHN bows uncomfortably .Lucy ? Theodore ? And now I want you all to tell Ernest and Helen what you told me — that their arguments against marriage are unanswerable , their logic unimpeachable , and we no longer have the slightest intention or desire to get them divorced by matrimony .JOHN , THEODORE , and LUCY look dubious . JUDGE crosses over and pinches them . HELEN and ERNEST are utterly bewildered .Why , we would n't let a little thing like marriage come between them for the world , would we , John ? would we , Lucy ? would we , Theodore ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: with an effortI agree with Uncle Everett entirely .

sp.speaker: JUDGE
sp.p: And you , Theodore ?

sp.speaker: Perfectly
sp.p: JUDGE

sp.speaker: And you , Lucy ?
sp.p: LUCY

div.stage: with a nervous glance at JOHN

sp.speaker: Absolutely
sp.p: JUDGEto the loversThere . You see ?

div.stage: ERNEST looks from one to the other in amazement .
